reviews.content: STAR RATING:*****Unmissable.****Very Good.***Okay.**You Could Go Out For A Meal Instead.*Avoid At All Costs.I used to be the biggest fan of the hit '80's cartoon,and disney,with their milions to spend on ludicrous,overdone special effects and nothing to add to the script,have gone and concocted an unspeakable adaptation,that was nothing like the show used to be.Matthew Broderick was wrong for the role.Chevy Chase or someone like that would have been better.This was absolutely nothing like the show used to be.The only good thing in it by half was Rupert Everitt.Avoid this christmas turkey of a movie,and see the old cartoons again instead.*

reviews.review_title: One Of The Worst Movies Of 1999.
reviews.content: When I went to go and see this film I was actually supposed to be seeing Bicentennial Man but our seats were already taken by friend and we had tickets! Weird, huh? Anyway so me and my mate thouht we would see Inspector Gadget.I thought okay, this movie is gonna be cool - but it sucked! It was so borrrrrrrrrrrrinnnnnnnnnggggggggggg and it has no story, no plot, the stupid gay Rupert Everett and dumb supporting actors.A miss at all costs!MY RATING : A half/10I only gave this a half out of 10 because of it reasaonable special effects.

I must admit. I was a huge fan of the cartoon series. Of course, I'm also a huge Get Smart fan and Don Adams fan. This movie falls far short for me. The problem? It doesn't take itself serious enough to come off. There is a line between not taking yourself seriously and being too serious. Some movies need to be on one side of the line. Some need to be on other. This movie just went way too far off the deep end.I won't say it's a bad movie for kids, but it's not a movie that most of the family will enjoy, IMHO.

(whirs, DING !)Here now is the review to Disney's 1999 live action feature, "Inspector Gadget." The whole reason why Disney made this movie is because, at the time, Disney owned DiC, the creators of the cartoon "Inspector Gadget," which I have enjoyed as a kid very, very much!!!!!So, the movie begins with testing a robotic foot. A bunch of thugs stole the foot (because it was possibly needed for their evil project), and a man with a Pinto (or was it a Nova?) was off to the rescue!!!!! Anyway, he got hit by a Yahoo!/Kodak billboard and needed to be hospitalized. What he didn't know was that he would be turned from human being to human robot!!!!! Now, he had the power to try to save the day!!!!! Will he? Let's find out!!!!!"Inspector Gadget" is a wonderful masterpiece; I've rented this when it came out in 12/99 and I liked it!!!!!10 stars(WHIR !!!!!)

Ok I admit, I was never a fan of the cartoon, but I decided to give this movie a try and the only people who will enjoy it are small children and Rupert Everett fans. He is the saving grace of the movie. Every one of his scenes is hilarious, although he alone cannot save this movie as much as I wish he could. Matthew Broderick seems to know how horrid the movie is and only gives what feels like half a performance, instead of savoring them in a burst of overacting delight like Everett or even Andy Dick. Adults everywhere will be rolling their eyes into the very backs of their heads when Dabney Coleman spouts off a "wowsers" at the end of the movie. I may have actually gagged at that part. And could someone please explain the stupid car to me. This movie is truly for people who like Rupert Everett, and even then have the remote ready because you NEED the fast forward button.

reviews.review_title: Good, but not as good as the originals
reviews.content: I enjoyed the movie very much.  It was funny, and it was similar to the classic cartoon.  However, there were a few things that didn't make it seem very nostalgic.First, you get to see Claw's face.  It would've been different you saw his face just in the end, but in the entire movie?  That's not like the cartoon!2nd, Brain doesn't have much of a part.  He doesn't really help Gadget.  It would've good if he couldn't talk, but helped Gadget.  That would've made it realistic as well like the cartoon.3rd, Mad Cat is missing.  Sure Dr. Claw holds cat, but he is never mentioned and only seen once!There were a few good things I did like.1rst, it tells the story of how Gadget became Gadget.  We get find out his real name as well!2nd, the Gadget Mobile.  I still like the old fashioned one, but this made the movie funnier.Overall, a good Disney movie.  Recommended to Gadget fans.

reviews.review_title: One of the funniest movies I've seen in a long time
reviews.content: This had "Disaster" written all over it; as Hollywood has plumbed television for so many of its recent films, the degree of quality has steadily dropped. So when you take a marginally funny kid show like INSPECTOR GADGET and put it on the big screen...well, let's just say I was expecting another THE FLINTSTONES and leave it at that.I was wrong.INSPECTOR GADGET proves that if you treat your audience with respect, and don't treat yourself or your subject matter too seriously, you can do nice things with film.  The entire cast is wonderful, with notable performances from Broderick and Everett.  It's not going to win the Palme d'Or or any Academy awards (except, perhaps, an effects award or two), but GADGET has a lot of heart, and is well worth seeing on the big screen.

Since I had loved the Inspector Gadget cartoon in the 80's, I went to see this movie. I wasted my money. The plot was very thin. Also, the movie could not keep me interested for long. I was glad it was over.If you want to see Inspector Gadget, watch the cartoon instead. It was much better than the movie.

I just saw Inspector Gadget today, and it was one of the most anticipated films of the year for me. Let me just say this, fun fun ,fun. If you remember the cartoon at all, you will appreciate it more then the average movie goer. Matthew Broderick plays bumbling security guard John Brown, who is blown to pieces by the evil Sanford Scolex{Rupert Evert} who loses his hand in the process and becomes the infamous Dr. Claw. Brown is put back together with the help of a Brenda{Joley Fisher}, the head scientist on the gadget project. With the aid of his new gizmos and gadgets, Inspector Gadget fights crime and makes the city of Riverton safe for everyone. I won't give any more of the plot away, I will just urge you to " Go Go to your theater" and see it.PS- My only complaint is the lack of Penny using the phrase " Uncle Gadget", but I digress.**** 1/2 out of *****

Not since Babe have I felt that I've been to a FAMILY movie. If you remember that this after all came form a cartoon you can really tell that everyone had fun making this movie. Matthew has his own style that is pleasant to see.

This was an enjoyable movie.  It seemed to be more of a set up for future movies, than a full script with no holes.  There wasn't a lot of plot, however, my 4 year old was engrossed and kept riveted to the screen the whole time.  It really was for this age group...3-12.

The basic plot: A low-rung security guard becomes a high-tech police officer and fights a villain.The praise:Mildly amusing occasionally and the actors do decent jobs.Actually,despite my negative standing on the film, Broderick tries hard but doesn't fully succeed.The flaws:It's gimmicky,desperate, and silly. It also has a hokey,bloated air to it, and it's unfunny. Nothing to watch. Dumb adaption of a great cartoon! This movie just fails on every imaginable level.

reviews.review_title: It's yawn yawn yawn from start to finish
reviews.content: It wasn't until I looked this up on the IMDB that I knew it was a Disney film (ie after the fact!) and it's not surprising.This was a cynical piece of money making, nothing more, nothing less.  A terrible script made worse by some nonsensical effects and some of the worst acting I have ever seen in my life, makes this a film that could send anyone to sleep.Its defenders would no doubt say it was a real life cartoon, and hence everything should be exaggerated.  Exaggerated, yes.  Bad, no.Matthew Broderick has sunk to new lows in his bad films, and who would have thought that possible?  In this case he plays two rubbish characters in the same film, with similar inability to each.Gives a new meaning to eminently missable.

reviews.review_title: It was fun but a little to sappy and dumb
reviews.content: I remember watching a little bit of the Inspector Gadget cartoons and liking them. But I'm afraid to say the movie is kind of a disappointment.I could tell the film makers tried to make it funny and likable but they overdid it and it ended up cheesy and sappy, sure I got some laughs out of it but it wasn't hooking. The story is about a goofy cop getting a complete make over and becoming a cyborg cop with a bunch of gizmo's and gadgets. Mathew Broderick deserves better he is a great actor and this film was bad for him. I remember seeing this as a kid in the theaters but now that I'm an adult it wasn't so appalling to me, little kids with love it, but adults might think otherwise. 6/10 for Inspector Gadget

reviews.review_title: Dumb fun for all ages. Really.
reviews.content: A cartoon so old, that the movie's target audience won't remember it.  A tough challenge to meet, and a best case scenario would be to create a film that kids born in the 1990's, and 1980's, and 1970's could enjoy.The film is no work of art.  Often I caught myself looking at meaningless extras and props because the camera shot seemed to tell me I should.  The editing, which is supposed to be "wacky," only sometimes succeeds, and other times feels like we missed entire scenes.  Andy Dick vanishes 2/3 of the way through the movie for no reason.But it's still a lot of fun.  The crazy dream sequence which opens the movie sets the tone perfectly, special effects blending kinda-okay with fast-paced action that would hold the attention of anyone with a good sense of fun. Parents taking their kids, or even parents/teenagers who just want to point and laugh for 100 minutes can enjoy how little this movie takes itself seriously.  Catch references from both "Godzilla" and "Last of the Mohicans" depending on how deeply you wanna dig.Rupert Everett has fun chewing some scenery in every scene, though the director seems to be working against him, editing around him for fear he'll steal the movie, or something.  He's _supposed_ to steal the movie.  He's Claw.  Just Claw.  One word.  Like... Madonna.Ah, well, the director only has one other film to his credit... "Cool as Ice."  If that doesn't qualify him for kiddie movies, what does?

reviews.review_title: may be not the best Disney film but a great movie if you don't take it too seriously
reviews.content: This was one of my fav movies in my childhold it was the first time I have seen inspector gadget I did not see the cartoon later on when I was about 6 or 7. inspector gadget's real name is john brown I like it better when he was called john so people could know what he's real name was but in the 2nd one he was called gadget which is what he was called in the cartoon. The 2nd one was not really good it ruined a good show and I was very shocked with the 2nd one they changed the actors like what they did in son of the mask oh yeah that was bad that was really bad. But I like this one its better then chicken little I like the part when robogadget pulls dawn john's pants on the bridge that was really funny and I love that talking car in this movie he had very nice coular which suited his character very nice before they changed it in the 2nd one I would really like to get this movie out on DVD if any one knows if it is still out on DVD please tell me thank for that. Great movie maybe not the best Disney film ever but still great 7.6 out of 10

This movie is something of an annoyance because its not really a movie. It's really a chance to see what special effects filmmakers can stuff into a short eighty minutes.  The film is more like a colorful novelty item used to keep kids quiet for a while. That car that's in it is possibly the most annoying thing in movie history. I don't know wether to say that because this isn't a movie. It's a total waste of time were Rupert Everett and Mathew Broderick make total idiots out of them selfs. I would like to take this opportunity to tell filmmakers to come up with their own ideas instead of using TV shows to make them into big screen productions. Let's face it they make pathetic movies(with the exception of The Rugrats)and don't go down well with fans of the original most of the time(i.e"The Avengers") I give this movie a 1 out of five.

reviews.review_title: Fun and Exactly what it sets out to be
reviews.content: All these disappointed people who expected some Superman or Batman, must have very high expectations of every kids film. I have not seen the cartoon, but I thought this was very well done and great effects, if somewhat frantic at just 70 odd minutes. Matt Broderick is an odd choice, but he gives the film a calm center, despite being the hero, and Rupert Everett is suitably horrible as the villain. I like the little comic touches and Broderick's cool humor is a change from Carrey like mania (as in The Mask, which I love by the way).The duplicate Broderick looks like a metallic copy rather than the actor just looking more stiff than the human version, and so some realistic antagonism ensues. (Better then Tom Cruise ripping a mask off to reveal he's really Dougray Scott in MI2- oh so believable!)Just the ideal Sunday afternoon film and having watched in on video some months ago, I think its still worth rating. It had some reasonable box-office so I cannot be completely wrong

to adapted a cartoon in film with real actors is always a challenge. and the success is surprising.but this film has not as ambition to be a successful one. in this case the great problem is to discover the purpose of story. an improvisation ? a joke ? a parody ? the only important thing, for me, is the presence of Rupert Everett and Matthew Broderick . the hard try to save a film about nothing or only a collection of clichés and gags in chaotic style. and this is not a real bad thing. but a sort of consolation. because you hopes to be a decent choice for the little children.

Ok, so this movie was made for children, but obviously not those children who actually grew up watching the cartoon (like me). I wonder if the creators ever watched it, since they got just about everything wrong. Lets start with Dr. Claw and his face, his face ?! Yes, it was always kept hidden from the viewers in the series. Here we get to see it in the first scene. When did Gadget become so smart? There's Penny, his niece, she used to be the real inspector in the series, because Gadget was just a mindless idiot. And Brain, his dog, who had to save Gadget from the bad guys over and over for the same reason. That's where most of the comedy came from in the old days, instead we get some CGI-slapstick and not all that funny if you ask me... and where are Dr Claw's henchmen ? Exactly, nowhere. Madcat is dubbed Sniffy. Chief Quimby suddenly hates Gadget, not because of his stupidity, but because he believes his police force is going to be replaced by Gadget-like cops ?! Oh yeah, they also felt it was necessary to explain how the inspector got his gadgets and that he used to be a security-guard called John Brown before that - why ? perhaps kids today are not allowed to have any imagination? So you didn't see the cartoon - you should, they took an original and funny idea, then stripped it of everything that made it funny. The actors are certainly not to blame , they did a decent job. You can a) rent it and keep the kids busy for an hour  or b) watch it yourself and have your chilhood toon memories butchered.3 out of 10 (for FX)

Ok, I loved the Inspector Gadget cartoons, and they beat this dissapointment. First off with the good points. It's a Inspector Gadget movie. Also the special effects are a positive. Now to the weaknesses. Hmm..where to start? I went into the movies expecting much. Only 78 minutes long! So I didn't get my moneys worth. Also, the plot was hollow and Dr.Claw(Rupert Everett) couldn't act.44%

If you're from Pittsburgh, you know that Dr. Claw's intimidating glass castle is just PPG Place.Otherwise, this is a movie with perfect cartoon to real-life casting. You have Matthew Broderick as the Gadget, Rupert Everett as Dr. Claw, Michelle Trachtenberg as Penny and Dabney Coleman - the most perfect of these casting decisions - as Chief Quimby.It then ruins all that good will by showing us Dr. Claw's face, a fact that never ever happened across every season of the cartoon.Perhaps the best part of this movie is the minions anonymous scene, in which a variety of henchmen appear, including henchmen include Mr. T and "Famous Bad Guy with Silver Teeth" (Richard Kiel as Jaws), "Famous Villain with Deadly Hat" (Richard Lee-Sung as Oddjob), "Famous Identifier of Sea Planes" (Bobby Bell as Tattoo from Fantasy Island), "Famous Native American Sidekick" (Hank Barrera as Tonto), "Bane of the Bumbling, Idiotic Yet Curiously Successful French Detective's Existence" (Jesse Yoshimura as Cato Fong from The Pink Panther), "Son Before Second Son" (John Kim as Lee Chan, number one son of Charlie Chan) and "Famous Assistant to Dr. Frankensomething" (Keith Morrison as Igor).After disastrous test screenings, the film was cut down from 110 minutes to 78 minutes. I have no idea just what was so upsetting in those 32 minutes, nor do I understand why this movie had to be any longer than 75 minutes.Disney still made money from this movie, despite scorched earth reviews, as there weren't a lot of kid-friendly films out in the summer of 1999. Throw in a bunch of cheaper direct to DVD sequels and a McDonald's promotion to make your own Inspector Gadget that had parents traveling hundreds of miles to complete and even the worst of films can be a success.

reviews.review_title: OK for what it is but surely most will consider this a missed opportunity.
reviews.content: Inspector Gadget is set in the American city of Riverton where lowly security guard John Brown (Matthew Broderick) yearns to be a real cop, one night while on duty at the Bradford Scientific Research Institute he witness a raid in which robotics scientist Artemus Bradford (Rene Auberjonois) is killed & a robotic foot stolen. John pursues the thieves but is badly hurt in a car crash, Brenda Bradford (Joely Fisher) the daughter of Artemus reconstructs John as a new high tech police officer cyborg with dozens of inbuilt attachments & gadgets. After being placed on the local police force & nicknamed Inspector Gadget John sets out to catch those responsible for his own & Dr. Artemus' death, the rich businessman Sanford Scolex (Rupert Everett) also know as Claw due to the fact he has a claw rather than a hand...Directed by David Kellogg one has to say that while it's not a complete disaster I feel a lot more could have been done with this live-action film of the popular Inspector Gadget (1983 - 1986) TV cartoon series that ran for two seasons & eighty-six half an hour episodes. I don't want to get all nostalgic here but I remember seeing this on British children's TV over here during the mid-eighties & was one of my favourite show's (along with The Trap Door, He-Man, The Mysterious Cities of Gold, Thundercats & the like, those were the days...) although I can't really recall any of it. Anyway, the script here was by Kerry Ehrin & Zak Penn & the main thing that stands out is that this Inspector Gadget live-action film is extremely silly & aimed squarely at younger children & I mean young because anyone with half a brain really isn't going to find any of this particularly funny. There are many, many scenes which are played purely for laughs which is fine because that what it evidently set out to do but for fans of the cartoon show this film has really, really dumbed it down to silly slapstick comedy with lots of CGI computer effects that kids will look at & say 'wow, that's cool' while anyone over the age of five will look at it & say something more along the lines of 'wow, that's silly & not very funny'. The plot is also lacking, again I know it's for young kids but I'm not a young kid so I'll call it as I see it & say the plot is poor, Claw poses no threat or menace whatsoever & barely even has a plan other than to build some robots to sell to armies worldwide. OK great, but since that motive is money driven & he's already a billionaire businessman I found myself asking the question why? The character's are slim as well, they are strictly one dimensional which again is alright for young kids but for anyone older than five it's not so good. At a mere 78 minutes (including opening & closing credits) at least it's short, it moves along like a rocket & it isn't boring.Director Kellogg does OK, the action set-pieces although silly & impossible to take seriously do have a certain energy & imagination about them. The CGI computer effects vary, some are very good like when Gadget uses his helicopter gadget to fly through the city but other's are terrible. It generally stays quite faithful to the cartoon with all the major character's included although they are presented in a different light here, Penny Inspector Gadget's niece for instance is no longer the brains who solves every case for her bumbling uncle, Chief Quimby is different & Claw is very different as well with no deep voice or metal hand & in the cartoon series his face was never shown. One thing I must mention though is that there is a lot of product placement & that Gadgetmobile is extremely irritating. The best jokes in the entire film come during the closing credits, the single funniest moment comes when Claw's henchman Sikes attends a meeting of the Minion's Support Group including Richard Kiel who played Jaws in the James Bond films & lookalikes of Oddjob & Nik-Nak as well as a cameo from Mr. T! With a supposed budget of about $75,000,000 this had a much bigger budget than I thought although I'd have said most of that went on the extensive CGI computer effects. The acting is as one dimensional as the character's the actor's are given, basically no-one is going to win any Oscars for this.Inspector Gadget is a Disney film aimed squarely at the younger audience which is fine I suppose but I would imagine a lot of teens & adults who grew up with the cartoon will be very disappointed with it, not unlike myself as it goes. It's strange because Disney usually make films that can be enjoyed by both the young & old but that's not really the case with Inspector Gadget. Followed by the straight-to-video/DVD Inspector Gadget 2 (2003) which is meant to be even worse than this, I shudder at the mere thought...

This latest cartoon-turned-motion-picture had me really excited.  I used to love the animated adventures of Gadget.  The movie was unfortunately a bit lacking, substance-wise.  The beginning of the film seemed very rushed, as the script tried to hurry into the main plot of the movie.  After the plot was well established, there seemed to be no character development at all, as Joe Brown instantly became Inspector Gadget.  The movie was also replete with plot holes, as the audience is left wondering "When did THAT happen???" on several occasions.  If you're looking for a cute remake of the TV show, bring your kids and let them enjoy it.  If you're looking for a great movie, you'll probably want to skip it.    Oh, and when the credits start, don't leave just yet.  Wait for a couple funny segments during the credits (including a great cameo).

Inspector Gadget (1999): Dir: David Kellogg / Cast: Matthew Broderick, Michelle Trachtenberg, Rupert Everett, Dabney Coleman / Voice: Don Adams: The cartoon was one of the funniest of the 1980's but this live action film version is pure junk. This regards an individual of many resources. Too bad the screenwriter had none. In the cartoon Dr. Claw's identity is never shown but here Rupert Everett waves the menacing object and far too early in the film. Setup effectively shows how Gadget came to be and his battle against an evil twin. Conventional with cartoon violence making one wonder whether director David Kellogg ever seen the cartoon? Special effects include numerous items hidden about Gadget's suit that are the film's one payoff. Everett holds certain charisma as Claw but in the cartoon he is concealed. This should have been handled with greater payoff as oppose to a celebrity appearance. Matthew Broderick is totally wrong as Gadget. Someone like Bill Murray would have been better casting. Michelle Trachtenberg looks nothing like Penny. The character had blonde hair and pigtails while Trachtenberg doesn't fit the profile. Dabney Coleman plays Chief Quimby with no exploding cigars, which was a running joke in the cartoon. Don Adams provides the voice of Penny's intelligent dog Brain. Pointless and rotten little heap. Score: 2 / 10

Disney made many finest pictures indeed, in this particular comics hero Inspector Gadget the idea was full range of possibilities to explore and should became a great comics adaptation to start, but even have a great support from ultimate generation of special effects by computer all things didn't work properly, if all this wasn't to celebrate neither to throw in the trash can, watchable droven to kids and families audiences, a bit childish's taste for me, but in someway everyone has a child inside anyway!!!Resume:First watch: 2007 / How many: 2 / Source: DVD / Rating: 5.5

easy comedy, adaptation of cartoons but very far by original, a too long joke. so, nothing special. the only problem is the ambition to be nice. because too many scenes are unrealistic at whole, absurd and fake. because the humor is to easy to define it as comedy. but, sure, for fun, only for fun without complications , it is a not bad choice.the second problem is the cast. Rupert Everett and Matthew Broderick are not the ideal option for a film about...nothing. so, only the conscience of chaotic work by director, the money and the need to give few drops of sense are excuses for this version. not the last,it remains the disappointment than it could be a decent movie. for entire family. but , maybe, it was not the team intention.

reviews.review_title: A decent movie, but not what it could(should) have been.
reviews.content: One of my biggest problems with the movie was the fact that Matthew Broderick had never even SEEN the cartoon before he was signed to play the part. Sure, it wouldn't have helped the movie any, but there's just something wrong with that! I think they spent too much time explaining where Gadget came from, a common problem with 'superhero' movies. Not to mention that they repeatedly called him John instead of Gadget. The movie was entertaining, but apparantly the writer/director thought that they could improve upon the original. And obviously, they were wrong.

Based on the animated TV-series of the same name, the origins of how Inspector Gadget came to be is depicted in this live-action film as he befriends the scientist who created him and goes after the bad guy, Sanford Scolex, who was responsible for his unfortunate accident.It's hard not to compare a film with something it was based off of, like a remake compared to an original or a movie compared to a TV-series. But, even as a stand-alone film, this movie was awful.There were no suspense or captivating moments in this movie, not even during the scenes where John Brown (Matthew Broderick) first realized he became a bionic being, nor during any of the investigative scenes. There were too many corny, childish and overzealous-acting characters like the excruciatingly annoying mayor and Scolex's dumb-founded minions. Even Scolex (Rupert Everett) himself is not menacing or evil-bent, but a vain, smug, and a clown of a villain.Inspector Gadget wasn't portrayed as much of a hero, but a clueless, bumbling idiot who couldn't even control his gadgets (at least in the cartoon, the inspector had this always-on-a-mission mentality and had control over his gadgets most of the time). Penny and Chief Quimby didn't contribute to the plot at all (and Quimby despises Inspector Gadget as opposed to the cartoon).The script was weak and the plot was rushed-through - it's just basically Gadget trying to capture Scolex (shouldn't he be called Dr. Claw at least?), with the Gadget Mobile doing most of the work. There were no intriguing subplots, no character development and no character chemistry. The special effects were OK to say the most, but this movie bombed big time. A very lame and unfunny movie which I wouldn't even recommend to children.Grade F

If your looking for a film to entertain the kids for a while, then Inspector Gadget is OK.  If your looking for something deeply engrossing and interesting then OK it is not.On the plus side there are some good SFX, but that is about all that it has going for it.Try 'The Iron Giant' instead.

Idk what everyone is going on about this being a bad movie. in fact its probably one of the greatest movies ever made. i remember loving it as a child and with the introduction of disney+ i have rewatched it and have found its even better than i remember. matthew broderick in his best role ever. forget that ferris guy officer john brown is where its at. i love the part where he grabs the mans balls and his eyes bug out lol. there could have been more fart jokes but its okay. this is one of the best movies ever made

reviews.review_title: Only suited for the kids, grown ups might get a headache from watching this silly nonsense
reviews.content: It's a silly cartoonesque comedy with live characters and animation, clearly only suited and targetted at kids, because I bet you a dollar, that grown ups will get headaches from watching this silly nonsense.There are better kids comedies out there. It's not terribly bad, but it certainly aint really funny either. But it could be a nice throwaway for young kids to watch...

reviews.review_title: A film that entertains without marveling, and that can frustrate fans of the cartoon.
reviews.content: Inspector Gadget was an amazing cartoon, but it had a brief stint on Portuguese television. I remember him, and I really enjoyed seeing him, but I don't remember seeing him much longer than four or five years. Despite this, it was one of the cartoons that I was most interested in as a child. The live-action movie we have here, however, doesn't do it justice... which doesn't mean it's necessarily bad. Plain and simple, the film is what it is: a piece of entertainment full of weaknesses.Designed to appeal to children and teenagers, I have serious doubts about the film's ability to appeal to adults, particularly fans of the original cartoon. It's not a bad movie, it's minimally funny and has some effective comic material, but most of the time it fails to make you laugh. Also, the film has bad dialogue and the script is quite poor and poorly written. So poorly written that I'm afraid of spoiling it if I say too much, so I'll limit myself to saying that the film follows the creation of Inspector Gadget and the birth of his archenemy, Claw.The cast is one of the most redeeming qualities of this film. Even with a basic story and very weak material on hand, each actor did the best they could, and I'm pretty sure they all tried to put in the effort and be professional. However, some did better than others. Rupert Everett, for example, makes the most of his charisma and steals our attention whenever he appears, with well-placed, sarcastic humour. Matthew Broderick doesn't do poorly in this job either, but he seems to find much more difficulties with his character. Joely Fisher is attractive but has little to do. Mike Hagerty and Michelle Trachtenberg are relegated to the shadows most of the time.Disney invested some money in the film, and it shows in the quantity and quality of the visual effects and CGI used. Gadget is very similar to the original, with the same clothes and the most striking gadgets from the cartoon, as well as the problems, confusions and breakdowns that have always characterized the character. The sets and filming locations help and do their part, as does the soundtrack, which contains a new version of the old cartoon theme song.

reviews.review_title: I don't understand why everyone hates this movie.
reviews.content: Ok I understand the part where you are used to the animated series if you ever saw it, but this was the first Inspector Gadget show I ever saw and it was my third movie i ever saw in a movie theater back in 1999 it was good times. I enjoyed it and Rupert Everett should do a spin off of his Claw character.

I really enjoyed watching the cartoon show as a kid. I was so glad that the producer made this cartoon a live action movie . This movie begins with John Brown a naive security guard, who dreams of being a cop one day, he is left raising little girl Penny. One day while chasing the bad guys, he gets into a car accident. The next day Dr. Brenda Bradford transformed him into inspector gadget. He could become the next best crime fighter, but the problem is he has too many surprise gadgets up his sleeve. Meanwhile an evil millionaire named Claw is trying to discover his weaknesses so he can rule the city. This movie had a lot action and comedy at its best. I hope they more like this one.

Inspector Gadget is a live action adaptation on the cartoon show of the same name starring Matthew Broderick,Joely Fisher, Michelle Trachenberg and Rupert Everett. A policeman named John(Broderick) gets seriously injured in a car crash brought on by Dr Claw(Everett). While in hospital he is transformed into a half robot/half human Cyborg. Will Inspector Gadget(now John is going for) be able to stop Dr Claw and save his city?.Overall this is a very very stupid film with cheesy special effects,a dire plot and childlike humor on top of that.I was also surprised to learn that one of the screenwriters wrote Free Guy and Ready Player One. Rupert Everett was decent as the villian yet his accent is distracting as it switches from American to Britsh and back again.5/10
2 1/2 stars.

reviews.review_title: Why the hate? I loved this movie as a kid, and I still find it entertaining!
reviews.content: I was obsessed with this movie as a kid, and even when I think about it now, I can see how it was silly and cliché, but it's still a joy to watch. I also knew this movie was based on a cartoon, but I knew nothing about the cartoon, and I knew about the movie first, so naturally I would assume that everything that happened in the movie is just like the cartoon, but I've read from other reviewers that this movie is so different from the cartoon. Since I never watched the cartoon, I'm reviewing this as a stand-alone film. This movie is really fun to watch; Matthew Broderick was the right man to play the title role, and he actually looks the part, I don't know why most people beg to differ, and Rupert Everett is funny as Sanford Scolex (aka Dr. Claw), and is sinister enough to get you invested, but the problem with his character is that he doesn't actually pose as a menacing threat to the society or to Gadget himself, he's more of a smooth talker. His henchmen are funny enough and they are great comic relief, but perhaps my greatest memory of this movie was the song, "I'll Be Your Everything" by Youngstown. That song is funky, it's a nice boy band tune, and it's good to listen to, but just recently, I found out that it's actually lyrically suggestive. For example the line, "So just call out 'Go-Go Gadget'", is actually, "I can freak you with my gadget", hahaha, lol, yeah I know, dirty, huh? The Robo-Gadget devil is funny, and he could've been the villain throughout, but all he does is wreak havoc around the city. The humor is good enough, and this movie is good, but I don't understand what pushed Disney to make a direct-to-DVD sequel, which was a complete travesty, and not worthy of being watched! I've only seen previews of the sequel, but that was enough for me to know that it's TERRIBLE!!! Overall, I like Inspector Gadget, and it's good for what it is, and enjoyable enough, especially if you liked it as a kid, if I were you, I wouldn't be so harsh towards the movie and just accept it as a stand- alone film. 8/10. Good job Disney!

reviews.review_title: I enjoyed it I won't lie
reviews.content: Another one rated too low, I assume that is due to it - so I read - not being "faithful" to the original television series. I have never watched that so I couldn't judge it in those terms, but as a film I enjoyed it I won't lie.'Inspector Gadget' is very silly but self-aware, in a similar vein to 'Looney Tunes: Back in Action' and 'The Cat in the Hat'. I enjoyed those two films and, while this isn't as good as those, I liked this enough. I probably wont ever rewatch, but I can see younger audiences finding enjoyment with it.There aren't, admittedly, any super noteworthy performances here, but that's not to say Matthew Broderick & Co. are bad in this - they give what's necessary. There's a few interesting cameos in there, too.There are a couple of fairly amusing moments, but it's the dumbness that I think they do well - it's stupid and they know it. Like those other films I mentioned earlier, you're gonna annoy a lot of people by doing that so I can see why this gets hate - I don't think 4.1 is fair though, but each to their own of course.

reviews.review_title: A great remake of a classic cartoon
reviews.content: If you didnt see the cartoon Inspector Gadget, or arent a kid (or both) you wont appriciate this movie.. and will probably sayit was another annoying slapstick waste of time.   But for those of us who have.. it was perfect! Broderick was a great Gadget.. all the clever phrases were there.. Penny and Brain, even Cheif Quimby.   My only complaints are very minor.. the car.. for one was annoying and Jar Jar Binksesque. And people kept saying wowser.. when the phrase is actually wowsers! but other than that it was great and got my vote as an 8.

reviews.review_title: Good, but not great, live-action cartoon adventure
reviews.content: John Brown is a security guard at the company where Dr. Brenda Bradford works.  One night the movie's villains break in to the building and steal her latest project.  In the chase, Brown is so badly injured he has to be almost totally rebuilt.  The result: a supercop called Inspector Gadget. Brown has trouble controlling his new powers, resulting in chaos, and then he must learn to handle the Gadgetmobile, a nearly 40-year-old Lincoln that talks and has a mind of its own.  This results in even more wild comedy. But Brown feels his powers are being wasted:  he mostly rescues kittens from trees.  The Riverton police chief does not like having a 'supercop' on the force anyway, and he is not eager to see Brown do anything important.  All of that changes when the villain, Sanford Scolex (also known as The Claw after his own injuries from the car chase), hires Dr. Bradford, who does not realize Scolex stole her project and apparently killed her father.  Scolex has also created an Inspector Gadget lookalike who is terrorizing the city. Can the real Inspector Gadget save the day?The visual effects are amazing.  Gadget's fingers turn into such things as a lighter and a Swiss-army-type knife, and his legs and arms can extend to many times their original length, among other things.  The fake Gadget looks computer-generated but is almost as amazing to watch. I don't know when I have ever seen such fast-paced action, and I would have preferred they slow it down some.  And Michelle Trachtenberg was adorable as Brown's helpful niece.  It was a fun movie.  The youngest ones probably shouldn't see some of the violence, but the music and sound effects constantly reminded us this was really a cartoon.

reviews.review_title: Nowhere as good as the cartoon, but still good nevertheless
reviews.content: I was about 12 years old when I first heard about this film, and I did like it. Now, at 21 years old and looking back at it, it's nowhere as good as the cartoon. The film does has its moments, and I did enjoy some parts, but overall, it's just not like the cartoon.The only good things I did enjoy was the opening titles (very well done), John Debney's music (which I wish was released!), and some scenes involving the inspector's gadgets.I'd like to end with a movie tip: when doing a film based on a cartoon (or anything for all that matter), don't hire a director that previously made another flop! Eg; David Kellogg, the director of Cool As Ice (starring Vanilla Ice)

reviews.review_title: Quite Good But I Was Expecting It To Be More Like The Cartoon
reviews.content: Inspector Gadget was a decent enough film. In no way does it deserve to be called bad but it will never be called the greatest film either.Matthew Broderick plays Inspector Gadget (who didn't even bother working his way up from Officer to Sergeant to...ah forget it) and he pits wits against Rupert Everett who plays the wicked Dr. Claw. The rest of the cast such as Joely Fisher, Andy Dick, Cheri Oteri, Michelle Trachtenberg and Dabney Coleman also do a good job.The film itself is plenty of fun. The opening scene is fantastic as Officer Brown (a pre-robotic Insp. Gadget) prevents a disaster and throughout the film there are plenty of great scenes especially those where Gadget faces his doppelganger.The film was good except that I expected it to adhere more to the cartoon version. Chief Quimby doesn't like Gadget at the beginning of the film whereas in the cartoon, Gadget was Quimby's top officer. Another thing was Dr. Claw. Rupert Everett did a good job as the bumbling Dr. Claw but I would have preferred a menacing and unseen Dr. Claw like the one from the cartoon. However, I guess change is inevitable when adapting a film from a cartoon.All in all, Inspector Gadget is worth checking out.

reviews.review_title: Yes, there IS a plot! Yes, it IS a good movie!
reviews.content: First off, let me say that I liked Inspector Gadget overall, and gave it a rating of 7/10.In looking over the comments here, I was a bit puzzled to see people complaining about the "lack of plot".WHADDAYA MEAN, THERE'S NO PLOT???  If there's no plot, there must be something wrong with my brain, because I had no trouble following the (supposedly nonexistent) plot.  I'm left to wonder if people are looking for something more complex than what they got.  Come on, this is a movie based on a kids' cartoon, of course the plot is going to be simple!I will admit, there is one glaring plot hole that bugs me, namely, on the day of the final battle, Pittsburgh (starring as Riverton City) looks in pretty good shape for a city that was supposedly torched by the evil Robogadget the night before.  I could also have done without the suggestive gag with Gadget and the eastern meditation guru....About product placement.  Yes, the Yahoo billboard and the Gadgetmobile's Coke/Skittles dispenser are blatant.  But some of the reviews I've seen give the impression that they dominate and/or detract from the movie.  Sorry, nitpickers, but they don't.  (Although the Gadgetmobile's line about having the Skittles knocked out of him was BAAAAD....)Aside from these few gripes, I thought the movie was very enjoyable.  The important thing to understand is that it's basically a live-action cartoon. That was my attitude going in, and it paid off with lots of laughs at the cartoonish sight gags.  Penny, though she doesn't get much screen time, still gets an important role to play in the films finale (contrary to what I heard, and therefore a delightful surprise); Gadget, though a bit smarter, is still as klutzy as ever; and the Pittsburgh backdrop is put to very good use.  And, it's about time Gadget got a girlfriend.  :)

reviews.review_title: Go go gadget but something went wrong
reviews.content: Disney knows how to turn animated and famous cartoons into live action figures it even ruined the original Inspector Gadget (1963) which was way better i even feel sorry for the late Rene Auberjonois the voice actor of Chef Louie (The Little Mermaid) and Andre (Planes: Fire And Rescue), this is the same thing that Disney also did with Underdog (1964) and turning him into a live action average dog (2007), not only it's the worst movie from 1999 along with the warner bros animated remake of The King And I. But it's even more worse than the Mulan (2020) live action remake and the Kim Possible (2019) live action remake from Disney Channel.

Inspector Gadget is a perfectly bland, kids-safe movie.  A few clever lines and the main character is likable enough.  But it's forgettable, and the special effects are not, well, that special.  One of the minor Disneys.

reviews.review_title: An average, forgettable piece of fluff for the most part
reviews.content: This 1999 live action Disney film is based on the 1980s cartoon series of the same name. I must confess, I'm not too familiar with the cartoon. I did see it a bit during my childhood (reruns in the '90s), but have very little memory of it. I had never heard of this movie until a couple years ago, as my last year of high school was drawing to an end. I got to see the first little bit of it in one of my classes, when we had no work to do. Eventually, it was interrupted by a fire drill, and by the time we were allowed back inside, the class was over. Two years later, out of curiosity, I have finally watched the whole thing, but it wasn't much fun.Officer John Brown is a security guard who is severely injured in an explosion, after a failed attempt to catch the evil Sanford Scolex! Fortunately, Dr. Brenda Bradford, who specializes in robotics, manages to save him by inserting cybernetic components into his body. This is how he gets the name, "Inspector Gadget", and with his new robotic functions, he becomes a police officer, which is a dream come true for him! However, many problems ensue for Inspector Gadget with his new functions and job. He must now battle Sanford Scolex (or "The Claw"), and stop him from carrying out his evil plans with stolen cybernetic components, but this will obviously be a challenging for Gadget, and sometimes, it may seem hopeless! In addition to that, the cybernetic cop finds that his gadgets don't always work! Many criticise this movie for how much it differs from the animated series that preceded it. Like I said, I'm not that familiar with the cartoon, so I can't point out any major differences, apart the one you obviously already know, one is animated and the other is live action. However, knowing how people have complained about many differences, I can't deny it, and can see why a fan or former fan of the show wouldn't be too pleased about it. Basically, I'm just going to have to focus on 1999's "Inspector Gadget" as a film. As a comedy, it's not very funny at all, in my opinion (I didn't laugh, or ever smile once). No horrendous gags, but no remotely funny ones, either, and some of them might be just a tad annoying, such as Gadget reaching out and accidentally grabbing the guru in a VERY uncomfortable place while blindfolded (in fact, as a guy, I found this a tad disturbing), and the scenes with RoboBrenda. Unfortunately, there's nothing to make up for this.This 1999 adaptation of the popular '80s cartoon show is, by definition, a kids' movie, and as such, I guess it's not so bad. However, for anything else other than a kids' movie, I suggest you forget about this version of "Inspector Gadget", regardless of what you may think of the cartoon series, or how familiar you are with that show. In my opinion, Gadget grabbing the guru in the most uncomfortable place is the most memorable part, but in a bad way. I doubt too many of us guys could forget that scene, as much as I'm sure many of us would want to! Apart from that, most of the movie is forgettable. If you want a Disney flick that can captivate many kids and adults alike, there are lots of those, but this is not one of them.

reviews.review_title: Well not quite the way I expected it to be
reviews.content:
According to bad reviews I was expecting like The Avengers Part 2 or something, but luckily I was proved wrong. OK this is cheesy at some points but what the hell I know the comic series from the TV so I was not surprised. What did surprise me though was that there were a bunch of self spoofs and a lot of spoofs from other films. I don't know what little kids (whom this film is meant to be for) think about it, but I liked it. All in all I found this film pretty OK, it was a bit cheesy of course (especially the henchman at the end) and I never really laughed but it was watchable due to the effects and the sphere it brought over. The thing I liked least about this film though were the jokes' at the end of the credits, they were really lousy and kind of messed up the actual ending, so my advice: do not watch the credits.
For me as an adult this was average, what kids think I don't know, hey I liked E.T. a lot when I was young and now, well does the expression yak!!!! Mean anything to you.
There are now actually but two things I want to say. The first is if you like this one, try RoboCop, which is by the way a Paul Verhoeven film, so don't try and watch it when your under 17 or so and the second thing is actually a question. That Kramer dude in Inspector Gadget (watch out for the freaky hair), is he a spoof of Seinfeld's Cosmo Kramer or was the Kramer in Seinfeld a spoof of Inspector Gadget????? Honestly I can't remember.
5 out of 10

reviews.review_title: Another one of my favorite childhood cartoons reuined
reviews.content: Inspector Gadget was one of my favorite cartoons growing up. I loved it! So i was excited to hear that they were making it into a live-action film. I thought man this is going to be a great movie. it sucked. It shouldn't have sucked, but it did. Thanks alot Disney for reuining a great cartoon. It wasn't even kinda good, it was all together terrible. Nice going, Disney.

I really enjoyed this movie as a kid I thought it was one of the funniest movies I'd ever seen. Matthew Broderick has and most likely always will be one of my favourite stars of the 80s through to the 90s classic especially in 'Ferris Buellers Day Off' I thought that movie was marvellous but back to this one. Inspector gadget is one of those movies you just have to see if you haven't already, very family friendly and hilarious wacky stunts are such a treat, me personally i loved the car, such a funny addition to the movie always cracking me up.I always enjoyed the cartoon of this so when I watched the live I wa so stunned at how accurate the movie was to the series, I love t when a movie lives up to its origin its always a fabulous feeling. I'll always have time to watch this movie any chance I get, truly phenomenal with such an intriguing story good enough to keep you entertained throughout as was I.Highly recommend! You wot be disappointed at all!

One reason to see this movie is if you are--or were originally from--Pittsburgh. The city is featured throughout, as Gadget was filmed Downtown. The Sixth Street Bridge and the South Side Slopes are shooting locations for this movie. The big glass building featured is PPG Place.

reviews.review_title: Energetic waste of time. Messy and fragmented. ** out of ****
reviews.content: INSPECTOR GADGET (1999) **Starring: Matthew Broderick, Rupert Everett, Joely Fisher, Andy Dick, Dabney Coleman Director: David Kellogg   80 minutes   Rated PGBy Blake French:Disney's new film, "Inspector Gadget" is about a cop named John who survives a major accident and is saved by a state of the art experimental operation that turns him into a robotic machine-like agent who has tools and contraptions of all sorts built into his body at his use when he says "Go Go," only to be called Inspector Gadget!The actual movie's structure is much like the body formation of Inspector Gadget himself. It is noisy, fragmented, energetic and consist of a bunch of half hearted contraptions thrown together to make something that doesn't have much in common with anything else present. The film is basically a series of zany action sequences that are kind of pasted together with characters and an uneven story that only kids between the ages of 6-9 would enjoy.The cop who is dramatically reinvented is played by Matthew Broderick, who, until "Inspector Gadget," was on a success spree with movies like "Election." His character becomes Inspector Gadget after an encounter with the film's heavy handed villain named Claw. He is played by Rupert Everett, who has already experienced catastrophe this year with the dreadful "William Shakespeare's A Midsummer Nights Dream."There is a romantic subplot in this movie as well as ample amounts of scenes involving Inspector Gadget's wacky body parts and mechanism elements. It has Gadget and Claw drooling over the attractive character Brenda, played by Joely Fisher, for both her looks and her knowledge of a specific invention made by her late father, who was earlier killed by Claw. Competition evolves into fight scenes and a reason for many happenings in the film. Also a major character is the Gadget Mobil, a life like automobile that is devised for Inspector Gadget himself. It is voiced by D.L. Hughly from the sitcom comedy "The Hughly's.""Inspector Gadget" is a movie that I found quite bad. I know, I am not exactly a target audience of the filmmakers, but even my ten year old relative found the film to his disliking. The movie is full of distinct flaws and obvious problems. I never found myself caring about the characters. There is no mood development beyond some neat opening credits, unlike the much worse 1997 film, "Mr. Magoo," which opened using clips of the original cartoon. Is it too much to ask for that same type of thing in this comedy-which is seldom funny and hardly ever convincing. The overall production design is nothing but a mess of incomplete sight gags and consists of one joke: Inspector Gadget's bumbling goofiness.In movies like this the audience lusts for boundaries-something to help make out what can happen and what can not. In "Inspector Gadget" there are no such boundaries. This is truthfully nothing more than a party time for the actors, who surly had lots of fun. I am reminded of another lacking comedy released a few years ago called "Blankman" which again, contained lots of props and energy, and the actors certainly had fun time with all the gizmos and props, but it too lacked something needed for every movie: audience participation.A character that I found being left out a lot is Gadgets daughter, who by the end of the movie, I still has not clue of what her name was. She is used only as a plot device-and I question how she was used to further the plot as well. For her presence brings nothing relevant or productive to the film. We never know her reactions to her father's operation or accidents. Thus, this is someone who could have been completely left out and would have not affected the movie a bit.In closing, I'd like to state that "Inspector Gadget" is an awful, insufficient excuse for a children's comedy. And believe it or not, I find myself comparing this film to last years violent and very anti-young audience action picture "Blade." I am stating once again that I had much rather have a movie where nothing happens than one in which everything happens. "Inspector Gadget" had so much going for it at the same time, it made literally made me dizzy.

reviews.review_title: If you are a fan of the (80's) cartoon stay away from this movie.
reviews.content: I was a big fan of the cartoon show when I was a kid, and if you are looking for a non fan-boy review this might not not be the place to look. But I will give two scores for the movie, one as a fan of the show, one for the movie on its own. When I first heard about this movie being made I was very happy, then I heard Matthew Broderick was going to play Gadget, I was surprised but still hopeful. Until I saw the movie poster, and my hart sunk.. They showed Doctor Claws face on the poster.. In the whole series you never saw his face.. If they had shown his face at some point in the movie as part of a major plot twist I would be o.k. with it, but showing what he looked like on the poster? That said everything, Disney didn't get it. And the movie was even worse. None of the things that I loved about the show were present, Brain is just a normal dog, instead of a walking talking one, Mad cat is just a normal cat, Penny is clueless, instead of the smart girl she is in the show, no "this message will self-destruct" no computer-book, but the worst thing of all, **minor spoiler** the Gadget mobile talks.**end of spoiler** If I hadn't watched and loved the show as a kid I could have been entertained by this movie. It's not that a bad movie on its own. And little kids will love it, there is plenty of action and comedy to entertain them. But if you are a fan of the (80's) cartoon, stay away from this movie. The only part I liked as a fan of the show was the opening credits, the movie version of the Gadget theme song was very cool, but that's all there was for me. As a fan of the show I give this movie 0, yes zero out of ten stars, on it's own 7 out of ten. That's a big difference is scores, but it shows how little the movie follows the show.

reviews.review_title: Does the classic TV-Show no justice..
reviews.content: I don't mean to be harsh but this movie does the classic cartoon absolutely no justice. I was an avid fan of the show as a child and couldn't wait to see the movie. Unfortunately it is not one everyone can see, it has been dumbed down way too much seeing the cartoon was a good show for the whole family. Them introducing new un-needed characters was also a mistake and the great Penny (Inspector Gadget's Niece) is rarely seen. The move to cast Matthew Broderick as Inspector Gadget was not a smart one. But I think the singular thing that puts the icing on the cake on this film's demise is that you see Claw's face right from the start, thus removing all sense of fear and secrecy from his character. It could've been done much better.

reviews.review_title: Not too bad but they made some bad casting choices.
reviews.content: I think I can enjoy this movie as I never really watched the cartoon series. Although there is nothing clever or intelligent about this film adaptation it still possesses some charm. Lets be honest gadget was always a moron and maybe that never was going to be able to translate into live animation but I didn't mind.I'm not sure how I feel about the casting choices. Broderick feels like the wrong choice to me. He seems to be too naively dumb instead of obliviously careless and dangerous. That is probably my biggest issue with this movie. Aside from that, the movie is not too bad and engages you if you are in the right mood.

reviews.review_title: I watched this as a kid......I hated it then
reviews.content: Ok....I recently attempted to re-watch this movie, I seen it as a kid and didn't get it or like it. That opinion hasn't changed. "Uncle Gadget" is played by a guy who just seems to not try to act. Penny isn't blonde and doesn't help Gadget solve the case and Dr. Claw isn't even close to scary as a villain and the car is annoying. It was just boring, unfunny and didn't work. Don't show Dr. Claw and make him creepy

Disney studios has created the best animated movies of all time.  WHAT IN THE HECK IS WRONG WITH THERE LIVE-ACTION MOVIES??!!  Did they even watch the original "Inspector Gadget" before they made this piece of crap?  I'm still disturbed that we actually got to SEE Dr. Claw. I'm still trying to find a similarity between the movie and the cartoon. I'll bet Walt Disney was spinning in his grave when this film was released.  This is all just a crying shame.

reviews.review_title: Is this a worthy live-action adaptation of the original animated series? Check out my review below!
reviews.content: "Inspector Gadget" (1999), I remember watching the original "Inspector Gadget" (1982-1986) TV series as a kid and enjoying it quite a lot. Even though I was born in 1992, they still aired reruns of the show. Whenever it came on, I always had fun watching it. So, as you can imagine, when I first heard about this "film" coming out, I was excited about seeing it. But sadly, I didn't enjoy it as much as I thought I would. It was just okay, in my opinion. Then, the more I watched it, the more I hated it. This "movie" has a cliched and boring story, standard to terrible acting and cheesy special effects. The plot is, a security guard named John Brown is involved in a near-death accident. Sanford Scolex a.k.a. Doctor Claw also winds up getting hurt badly in the accident as well, which results in him becoming Doctor Claw. From there, John is transformed into a cybernetic police officer, which will help keep him alive. The opening scene leading up to him being transformed into Inspector Gadget was honestly pretty well-executed. That was all well and good, showing a similar fate between the primary protagonist and antagonist. However, there's one glaring issue here, the villainous Doctor Claw's face was fully exposed! In the original animated show, Doctor Claw was never shown. He was always a hidden character, which made him all the more intriguing. Just when you thought that there couldn't be anymore issues, you haven't seen anything yet! After John Brown becomes Inspector Gadget, Doctor Claw plans to take over the world (how original!) From there, it's up to Inspector Gadget to stop him. They got the concept correct, but the execution was so terrible that it almost doesn't seem real. For the most part, I just thought: "what am I even looking at?" It's like the story doesn't know where to go, and it's just random with nothing of substance happening! This "film" is nothing but non-stop extreme nonsense with an onslaught of unresolved subplots and then it ends. As for the acting, it's just as weak as the plot. But, the worst performance comes from the main star himself, Matthew Broderick as John Brown/Inspector Gadget. Just like the storyline, his acting is all over the place. It's like he doesn't know what kind of performance to give, so he keeps changing it up with every single scene. Also, his line delivery is off as well. With nearly every sentence he speaks, it's never focused on just one specific emotion. An inconsistent performance always results in a confused audience. Rupert Everett is also a letdown as Doctor Claw. When you look at him and listen to his voice, you would never know that he's supposed to be Doctor Claw! The rest of the cast is just standard to bad with their acting. As for the special effects, most of them are passable. However, the majority of them have not aged well. Especially the CGI effects! At least they do try to incorporate some practical effects here, and a lot of them are good. But, even those can get a little bit cheesy at times! Another thing, the editing is horrible. Some of the shots and angles are so poorly composed, that you can't even tell what's going on! Also, some of the shots last for less than a second. Why would they include those shots when you can barely see them? Overall, the special effects are just hit and miss. Now, let's get to the only two positive elements in this "film", which are the sets/locations and the soundtrack. All of the sets/locations are fantastic and give the "movie" a decent atmosphere. Finally, the soundtrack composed by John Debney is well-done. His film score really sets the tone for the plot. If only the story was actually worth it, then his film score would've had more meaning to it! John Debney has written a lot of great movie soundtracks, and this one is no different. "Inspector Gadget" is one of the worst live-action adaptations of an animated TV series I've ever seen. Had it been completely void of any redeeming qualities, then it would've been on one of my top ten worst lists! You just watch this "movie" and gain next to nothing out if it. I rate this "film" 2 out of 5 stars on my scale, which equates to 4 out of 10 IMDB stars. Just stick with the original animated "Inspector Gadget" TV series, because this "movie" does very little justice to it. All it does is leave scars that will never heal. Whenever I think of this "film", I cringe! Now, I know what you're all thinking. "What do you think of the sequel?" Well, that'll be a whole different review for another time. Bottom line, just avoid this "movie" like the plague. Instead of saying the phrase, "go, go, Gadget!" You'll just be yelling: "go, go, go away, movie!"

Inspector Gadget (1999, Dir. David Kellogg) When Security Officer John Brown (Broderick) is horribly injured after chasing after a killer, Dr. Brenda Bradford (Fisher) sees it as a perfect opportunity for her new project to take place. When John wakes up, he finds his body changed. John Brown is now Inspector Gadget; a cybernetic police officer whose first plan is to hunt down the killer of Bradford's father (Auberjonois).Irritating sound effects and a basic storyline will keep youngsters occupied, but grown Inspector Gadget fans might find it a big step away. Matthew Broderick and Rupert Everett do a good job but nothing memorable.Justice will be served. - Officer John Brown (Matthew Broderick)

What is it with Disney movies? Inspector Gadget and Herbie Fully Loaded are just two of the reasons that I think that they're (almost) unwatchable.Perhaps it's just to cater to 'the kids' - like Lucas did with his new trilogy - that they 'hipped up' everything even at the cost of losing the spirit of the cartoon.Inspector Gadget was one of my favorite cartoons - I used to tape every episode on Betamax (and I even taped over a rented Top Gun beta because I didn't check what was in the Beta!) - and I was really hoping (perhaps against hope) that Disney would do it right for a change.This offering is nowhere NEAR the Cartoon Inspector Gadget. At best it shares the character and the basic storyline but it has none of the 'smarts' and attraction that the cartoon did. As many other reviews mentioned almost everything in this movie is 'non-canonical'.First off, Matthew Broderick as Gadget? Come on! What's Colonel Robert Gould Shaw doing there pray tell?? He talks just the same way he did in Glory (and I love that movie by the way) not in that very strange high pitched Inspector Gadget voice. And John Brown? PLEASE! When did this become a Civil War picture? Second, attitude. Inspector Gadget is a cartoon Clouseau, he's a clueless Mr.Incredible, he THINKS (and everyone else thinks) that he's doing it all with his gadgets but it's really Penny and Brain! Third, Penny and Brain. This is where they really botch it big I think. The central premise of Inspector Gadget (the cartoon) is CHILD WISH FULFILLMENT - it's letting the child viewer identify with Penny and Brain, it's almost like Charlie Brown and Snoopy as detectives (well maybe not Charlie Brown, but you get what I mean, a child and their pet out on a great adventure). Sure, Gadget is the vehicle that makes the show move but Penny and Brain are the ones that solve things. There's also that super computer book which (before the internet) was just the coolest thing - the information of the world at your fingertips.They brought Scooby and Garfield to life, why not Brain? This is a really important point I think. This is certainly why I watched - and the thought that for a 12 year old kid Penny was smart and smart=sexy. Disney used to do this so well - how could they miss the mark so badly here? Third, Dr.Claw - he's Jaws (the shark). You don't show the shark till the end and maybe not even then. Even in the cartoon intro when Gadget puts the cuffs on him and it's a bomb. That's just the best. Why bother showing his face? Would you show the face of the neighbor in Home Improvement? Fourth, the wise-ass mobile. That really spoiled it for me big time at first viewing. What is this Shrek and Donkey except Broderick's 'security guard' with no attitude is less of a character than Shrek? The Gadget mobile was almost like one of the Bond mobiles - can you imagine the Bond mobile shooting its mouth off like that? Too much stupid and unnecessary updating.I don't know why they even bother, except for lucrative gain. Those people are all special effects and NO form, NO substance. They never did their homework and found out what made Inspector Gadget tick. Heaven forbid they do 'Where in the World is Carmen San Diego' the movie!

reviews.review_title: I'm embarrassed for this site liking this ugly nightmare
reviews.content: Inspector Gadget, Igor, Megamind...what do all these have in common?The answer is: they're all painfully unfunny, they all look completely the same (i.e. Cheaply animated) and they're all written by "comedy" writers with the apparent mental sophistication of a small monkey. Writers who think Abusing animals & using them like punching bags is hilarious.Inspector Gadget is almost like the quintessential blueprint for "cheap, poor taste, poorly live-action "comedy"".Here's the entire joke of the series; hold your sides in case they split. "The monkey gets bullied and abused (hahaha so funny!) and unpleasant (ahahaha) and the main kid whines a lot (ha...ha....haa...)".Do you get the joke? It's funny because Beast Wars did these jokes prior this show *constantly*. Isn't that hilarious? No?Hm. Well, if that's not funny, what if we do it a million times? Surely that will be hilarious?It's almost agonising explaining the concept because this whole show is so painfully stupid. It's designed by people who are either stupid or simply lazy in order to appeal to other people who are stupid and/or intellectually lazy.If you're forced to be subjected to this awful film, at least treat yourself to The Happytime Murders. It's like an antidote to this fatal poison.(Oh, and I haven't even mentioned that the main character is a mockery of a literal monkey that the writers know nothing about. Because trying to ruin a kid's life by portraying them as an ass in a TV show is a totally moral thing to do. Disgusting).

reviews.review_title: I loved it for what it is and not what it is not
reviews.content: Personally I loved the movie. I was a fan of the cartoon as a kid so as soon as I heard it was being made I had to see it. While there were obvious changes they were never to point that it mattered too much. And some differences were inevitable. But the main things like the gadgets and the look were just right. His outfit was the most important part for me and it was spot on. Having the car talk was a nice addition which I enjoyed a lot. The movie was cute and funny. A fun Saturday afternoon movie with a group of girlfriends. It has since been watched in my house many times by many different people of many different ages. Mathew Broderick was really great as the title character. Much better than I thought he would be. And Michelle Tractenberg is much as I imagined Penny would be. So many people took it too seriously but when taken for what it is a (children's) Disney movie. It so much more enjoyable.

"Inspector Gadget" the cartoon show was a funny, light-hearted romp not unlike other cartoon shows made before the duldrums of Congressional legislation changed the kids TV market. The show featured a half-man, half-robot, half-witted policeman (voiced flawlessly by Don Adams of "Get Smart" fame) and his adventures solving crimes with MUCH assistance from his niece Penny and faithful dog Brain. Having loved the TV show immensely, I immediately saw the film upon its release. Now there's one 5 dollar bill I'd like back.I should have known how bad the movie version would be - having seen the bad commercials and the inevitable McDonald's promotional tie-ins. And to top it all off, the movie was produced by Disney - notorious for butchering perfectly good source material for their own profit. Just look at "The Jungle Book" and "The Little Mermaid", movie adaptations that are far from what the original authors of each respective work had in mind. Disney has once again chopped up its source material - this time one of my favorite cartoons.Matthew Broderick is the predictably youthful choice to play Gadget, the man with more inventions than a swiss army knife and less brain cells than an organ grinding monkey. Had Disney wanted to make a movie more pleasing to a broader audience the natural choice to play Gadget would have been the voice of Gadget himself - Don Adams. Even considering that this is a kids movie, Broderick is extremely hammy and not at all funny as Gadget. Equally bad is Rupert Everett as Claw - he's about as intimidating as a housewife with a bad manicure.The good news is the supporting cast is solid. Michele Tractenberg makes a good Penny (although the cartoon Penny was blonde, not brunette) and Dabney Coleman is good as Chief Quimby. Cheri Oteri as the mayor and DL Hughley as voice of the Gadget mobile are also solid for the few scenes they appear in. Joely Fisher is good as Gadget's love interest.The worst news is that the movie ignores almost everything fans loved about the cartoon. Penny is nowhere near as smart as she was in the cartoon and Gadget nowhere near as dumb. It is apparent that no one involved in the making of the film knew anything about the material upon which the film was based. The Gadget-copter is called a "Gadget-chopper" and even Gadget's catch phrase "Wowsers!" is sans the 's'. While some criticize the cartoon as being empty-headed and formulaic, the movie is dumber and scatterbrained. It seems like the filmmakers filmed a bunch of stuff they thought would be entertaining and filled in the gaps as they went along. The plot is so scattered - the evil Gadget subplot seems tacked on - that it makes no sense whatsover.No doubt kids, who care nothing about plot and will laugh at anything will find this movie entertaining. The old fans of the cartoon will groan in pain though. The movie gets a 9 for some nostalgic value and a -1 for entertainment value.

reviews.review_title: Wasn't as bad as everyone said it was.
reviews.content: This movie isn't as bad as everyone said it was. The only thing I hated was Rupert Everett playing Dr. Claw. I wish Dr. Claw was like the character like the  cartoon. Other than that I don't know why it got such bad reviews. I recommend this movie to anyone who likes a good family movie.

The reviews here in Atlanta have been far from kind. Inspector Gadget was actually much better than I expected. It was light entertainment but 'good' light entertainment! It was fun, quick and a good ride. Our kids loved it and we liked it a lot. What more do you want for your money?

reviews.review_title: It is difficult to take a cartoon and make it into a movie.
reviews.content: Inspector Gadget is a movie for those 13 and older and who like the slapstick comedy movies. No one said that it had to be like the cartoon and it really isn't. It is difficult to take a cartoon and make it into a movie. Everybody has different expectations as to the storyline and the character development. It is a story in its own right. It is a good movie for the family to watch together and get a good laugh. Matthew Broderick always reminds me of Ferris Bueller. So, his comedy is similar. It is an entertaining movie and goes well with either popcorn or pizza and a soda. So enjoy the movie for its entertaining value to put a smile on your face and have you forget about your troubles during the flick. Can't really ask for more of a comedy.

reviews.review_title: Avoid this movie like the plague
reviews.content:
Luckily I did not pay to see this movie.  Also, I cannot even reveal any spoilers because I willingly WALKED OUT after forty minutes of the movie. It was that bad.  I laughed once, when the Yahoo! billboard fell on the guy, and the theme song came on.  However, that was only because I thought it was making fun of it, but then I realized it was yet ANOTHER product placement. 
I loved the cartoon.  I used to watch it almost religiously.  (although i missed the last episode.  I heard that they show Dr. Claw and it was nothing more than a Claw, somebody comment on the show's page)  The cartoon had Penny and Brain alot more than the movie had, as to that point.  I hated the setup of the whole thing, reminiscent of Robocop.  Then Broderick screws with the whole feeling of Inspector Gadget.  He is not nearly as clumsy as the cartoon was.  Another fact is his gadgets actually work to the point I saw, except for the oil slick.  He also screwed with the tone of "Wowsers" which used to be in an excited tone.  I felt so disappointed that they slaughtered the cartoon so badly.  Everybody else felt that way too.  Us 14-17 year olds remember the cartoon fondly and we loved every minute of it.I went into the movie with an open mind, knowing that they would have screwed with the cartoon.  I was taken aback at how retarded the movie was. It relied on sight gags, and stupid dialogue for humor.  Disney relies on pain and physical humor to push a kids movie along.  Product placement is pointless in this film, and it shows.  The wise-cracking car is not that good at cracking wise.  The gadgets look nice, but they were almost overly glossy.  The cartoon was a better look.  The silly scenes were crap.  In the 40-45 minutes I watched the movie, not one laugh was heard, and they laughed at the Dudley-Do-Right preview.  This movie should not be watched by people who want intelligence in their family entertainment.  I highly recommend "The Iron Giant," which was sad, but very very good.  This movie is a travesty to the whole family drama.------------1

reviews.review_title: Well, at least it's better than Disney's other tries.
reviews.content: Inspector Gadget, a 1980's cult cartoon is cleverly remade by Disney.  It has recaptured the doofy Gadget look and feel.  The Special Effects are very nice and the actors... Well sort of.  Broderick is a nice Gadget but he's at his peak when he's the Evil Gadget.  Everett plays a good Claw with a nice looking... claw.  The Gadget Car was annoying though.  But it was a nice movie.  I suggest you stay at the credits because you'll meet an old friend from a very distinctive Spy Movie.***

I have been waiting to see this movie for a long time. Finally, the day it opened I went to a new theater that has that "stadium" seating, and saw the movie on the first showing. The movie was fantastic! I was interested to see how they would explain how Gadget becomes Gadget and how Claw becomes Claw. They did it in a zany-way, more so for Claw's hand, which is crushed by a flying bowling ball! Matthew really does bring the cartoon to life, as he portrayed Inspector Gadget almost flawlessly. The movie was a little shorter than I expected, but I guess that is so the kids (the main audience) can keep attention at all times. I did have a few pet peeves with the movie. For one they are in "Riverton" and it is suppose to be "Metrocity". Second, Penny does not have a computer book or her communicator watch ( she gets the watch at the end during the credits). Third, Dr. Claw is just Claw (one word, like Madonna;) ) and, he does not have an organization called "MAD". Not to mention, we see his face, unlike in the cartoon. But, still, the movie was great and let me say the Gadgetmobile was super fast, funny, and awesome. I hope they come out with Gadget Part 2. I have already seen the movie three times total!
