at least it was for me. Matthew Broderick is a good actor and all, but the only thing he could offer in this movie was his looks. His voice was all wrong! Broderick is too soft spoken, while the cartoon Gadget had a harsh, nasal sound to him that made him instantly recognizable. Even the music video was a drag. Nothing to offer us fans, except the bloopers at the end where Brain speaks, and I yelled out, "It's him! It's Gadget! That's him!" amid stares. At least Captain C. wasn't in this.

reviews.review_title: Not quite good, but not bad
reviews.content: I'm a big fan of the original cartoon, so I waited with baited breath for the big-budget "Inspector Gadget" movie. What I got was something that didn't quite live up to the series, but something that was at least a decent movie. I think Rupert Everett is the decent choice for Dr. Claw, but he should've been instructed to make the character a lot more sinister and scary. He also needs a better evil laugh.The plot is okay, the effects are okay, the acting is okay - the movie is just "okay," and therein lies the biggest problem. The TV series always took itself seriously, because even with goofball antics, Dr. Claw is always genuinely trying to take over the world. The movie lacks this tension, and, as a result, doesn't work as well as it could have.7/10

Ok I have seen bad movies but this is one was something else. Inspector gadget is by far the worst thing I have even seen. I actually wanted to walk out but there just wasn't any time for that, the movie was only ONE HOUR LONG. It wasn't any longer than many TV shows.  Now the movie is categorized as part comedy but there was not a single joke or anything close to one. This "movie" is suitable for 8 year olds and lower and not for anyone else.When the movie was over I felt cheated and certainly felt like I wasted my money. THIS MOVIE IS NOT WORTH EVEN SEEING ON TV! Ohhhhh god I just can't tell how bad it really was!!!!

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as I thought it would be!
reviews.content: Okay, maybe you do need lower expectations to enjoy this movie, but I thought that a vivification of a child's cartoon series would be really stupid, and it was actually kind of cute. I enjoyed Matthew Broderick's portrayal, and the gadgets were imaginative. My husband and I both got a few laughs out of it. There are also tons of crazy credits at the end of which we only caught a few - hope someone else got them and can post them on this site so I don't have to rent the video just to read them! Also, the closing credits go on forever but if you have time to kill, stick around because there is something at the end for you diehards. One question: why would anyone need THAT MUCH toothpaste?

reviews.review_title: Go Go Gadget Movie Review ***1/2 out of 5
reviews.content: Since I was a child I've been a huge fan of the Inspector Gadget cartoons. I don't think I could have asked for a better movie version.Matthew Broderick is great as the inspector. Rupert Evert is great as Claw too. You will hear a lot of people complain that in the cartoon you never see Claw's face and in the movie this is not so. I say, so what? Rupert Everett more than made up for that by his hilarious facial expressions. He practically steals the show.The special effects are terrific. There are moments where the film seems almost apocalyptic, what with the shots of the helicopter flying down over a burning city and all.John Debney's score is absolutely perfect. He incorporates the theme quite well into the score and uses it as his prominent theme in the movie. Good job!It's extremely colorful, it's zany, and whacked out just like it should be. If you liked this, I would highly recommend the sequel as well.

Obviously the first of what was hoped to be a series of live-action adventures based on the comic book character, because it's about how he gets started, and the solving of his first big case.  That is, he is rather "green."  The point is not about how "well" he can do with his gee-wiz gizmos and eye-popping special effects, but rather with his bungling attempts to learn how to use them.  So he comes off as a kind of "RoboRube," less intelligent than his automobile, and even his 12-year-old niece routinely upstages his character.  The bad guy emerges as the most interesting character, skillfully played and immensely enjoyable.  In contrast, Gadget and the rest of the cast seem thin and colorless.  On the other hand, the whole point of the film is about gadgets, so there not-being-much-else shouldn't matter.

reviews.review_title: Disney brings back the world's "bumblingest" inspector -- Inspector Gadget!
reviews.content: From 1982 to 1985, kids everywhere tuned in their televisions to see "Inspector Gadget," an animated show about a bumbling detective and his niece Penny. After years of reruns, Disney has recently bought the Inspector Gadget rights and decided to make a movie. It's everyone's favorite inspector, but with a twist. If you liked the cartoon, the movie is a must-see. How many of us remember questions about Doctor Claw (the criminal mastermind) and his true identity. The movie clears up many mysteries that the show left untouched. In the movie, policeman John Brown is nearly killed in a car accident and is given an old scientist's experimental project, the "Gadget Project." When "Gadget" falls in love, and "Claw" (not their real names) kills the woman's father, Gadget vows revenge. With Penny's aid, and the brand-new Gadgetmobile, the Inspector has more than 14,000 gadgets. All aspects of the original cartoon are brought into play: Mad Cat (Claw's pet), Quimby, Dr. Claw's never-seen face, and even the original theme music! With Rupert Everett as Dr. Claw, Michelle Trachtenberg as Penny, and Matthew Broderick playing Gadget, Robo-Gadget, and John Brown (wow! three roles!).

Saw "Inspector Gadget" this past weekend by default - my friend rented it. If you don't pay $$ to see it, then it's worth watching on some lazy Sunday Afternoon - mostly on account of the fact that it's only 74 minutes long. Likes: Matthew Broderick and the Don Adams cameo, plus the "Minion" skit during the credits. Dislikes: the politically incorrect "afro-american" Gadgetmobile - (why they needed a "talking" car was beyond me and the ), the blatant advertising for both YAHOO.com and Skittles (at one point the whole screen fills with a billboard that says "Do you Yahoo" before our hero crashes into it), the Claw being shown as an "everyman" rather than the obscure villian he was in the show, and the fact that it just wasn't all that fun - a little too much slapstick humor and some jokes that fell flat. Go-go Gadgetscriptwriter! A very small recommendation for those with an hour to spare --- 6.9 out of 10 - a D+.

reviews.review_title: It was O.K, but it could have been a lot better
reviews.content: When I went to the movie theatre, I had a choice between Inspector Gadget, and Tarzan. Unfortunetly, I chose Inspector Gadget. I'm not saying that its a bad movie, but it could have been a lot better. Matthew Broderick fits his part well and his acting improved since Godzilla. In the end I would recommend this movie to people between 7 and 13 years of age. I give this movie a 7 out of 10.

"Inspector Gadget"Nothing brings about sweaty palms quite like a Disney live action movie event. This time the Mouse has a beloved 80's cartoon to work with and a huge effects budget to bring it to life. I really was hoping for something good, but I knew in the corners of my mind that Disney just can't pull this type of film off anymore. With Walt gone, all this material means to the company is Happy Meals and video sales. "Gadget" is an outrage of giant magnitude. The latest in a string of Disney live action family films with no class and no respect to the viewer.If anything is inspired about "Inspector", it might be the casting of Matthew Broderick as our multi-gadgeted hero. Broderick still has the right amount of fresh faced charm and honest personality for the role. I doubt anybody else could have been a better choice to play the character, but then again I can't see anyone else taking the part after reading the script. The plot is basic, evil Claw(Rupert Everett in an embarrassing performance) vs. good Gadget. They also take the time to show us the origins of the characters, something the show never did. I would like to know why, in each of these cartoon or comic based movies, do we need to show the character foundations. "Gadget" would have been a lot more satisfying if they just dropped us in on the action and skipped the needless back story.Distressing, almost hilariously so, is the use of Gadget's "thought balloons" for three key moments. It's no secret that this film tested very poorly and was continuously edited down to the current bare bones running time of 80 minutes. What was deleted was basically every inch of narrative(check out the Evil Joely Fisher, in purple latex, that comes out of nowhere and then leaves even quicker) and character, leaving only the action and more action aspects of the movie intact. I submit that this might be the first film that could legally be diagnosed with ADD. But back to the thought balloons... Some scenes that were cut are back in the film in spilt-second memories that Gadget has about plotlines that were excised. Each contain effects that I know Disney ordered back in due to the high cost of creating them. In the middle of all the noise we get Gadget remembering more noise. It's weird to describe it, it's even weirder to see it.Since this is Disney flick, the filmmakers also include heaps of product placement. To those who found the gratuitous "Austin Powers 2" beer plug distasteful should stay away from the "Gadget" McDonalds, Skittles, Coke products, Tommy clothes(see below), and most blatantly, the Yahoo Internet corporation plugs. I've come to expect this behavior, but the discretion in which the placements are being presented is getting faint.
With the use of a huge budget the film does have the unique virtue of fully fleshing out the Inspector's gadgets. I'm trying hard not to be a sour puss, so I will heartily admit that the special effects are great. They colorfully display Gadget's trinkets more realistically than I could have imagined. The filmmakers deserve credit for the creation, but they ruin it with Gadget constantly in the midst of mayhem. There should've been more opportunities for Gadget to breathe, for the audience to get used to madness. No such luck. "Gadget" runs at full steam from opening credits to closing credits.Almost sacrilegiously, the filmmakers have also decided to tamper with the essence of "Gadget". Niece Penny (sharply played by Michelle Tractenberg, in full Tommy Hillfiger gear) and canine Brain were, in the cartoon, the real reason Gadget got out of trouble. The real inspectors behind the Gadget. In this film, the two are quickly introduced and then quickly forgotten. The film relies on Gadget alone to solve the crime. He bumbles has way across town while Brain and Penny sit and watch. By taking out the essential charm, why did they even bother to make the film? Oh yeah, to sell toys.
"Inspector Gadget" is the bain of current children's cinema. The nation complains about violence and the impact on children, all the while blaming movies aimed at adults. The real enemy are these frenetic kid's films with nothing redemptive about them. "Gadget" is a one-note weapon of mass distraction aimed at kids all over the country. Take my advice and go, go, go to a different movie.--------- 1

Inspector Gadget is not a good film. Some kids may like it because of the hero, the gadgets and the simple story-line, but it's not a good movie. The plot is weak, EVEN FOR AN ACTION MOVIE(this movie is like an action film for kids), the special effects are nothing special and the characters are a bunch of walking clichés. One positive thing, the acting is surprisingly good. Matthew Broderick is good but has a bad role and Rupert Everett is a good villain: I believe he would be a good James Bond villain. The rest of this movie is unoriginal(but at least its not a total rip-off of something else) and pretty lame. Then again, I'm not the target audience...4 out of 10.

Go, go, bag of rubbish. Not really clear why it's called "Inspector Gadget". If you remember the TV cartoon, then you too will be puzzled, since only the character names are shared. Gone is the wit, the bumbling Inspector, the clever Brain. In their place are gormless imposters. Gone is the simplistic but comforting plot of Qumiby calling on Gadget, Gadget in trouble, Penny/Brain saving the day, and Claw finishing "I'll get you next time, Gadget. Next time!" In it's place is a convoluted story, and crap acting, and annoying characters. This film has no redeeming qualities, and is simply a thief of time. Remember, you won't get that time back. Go, Go Disney decline.

First of all, I haven't seen a Disney movie for a while, so I had to get used to the specific style that is so typical for these movies. But seeing Matthew Broderick as the hilarious Inspector Gadget made it all right. From the first scene to the so predictable end - those who have seen a dozen of Disney movies know what I'm talking about - ,it is filled with action and cartoon-like moves. Rupert Everett, who played Inspector Gadget's life long enemy Claw, had his hands full building RoboGadget. This new clone of Gadget terrorizes Riverstone. Together with his talking car - oh man, that was almost Herbie - they fight crime and try to stop the second Gadget from destroying the town. You must see it once, and since we're talking about a Disney movie, it won't take long before you get to see it on TV.

reviews.review_title: How to ruin a childhood classic
reviews.content: Seriously who thought it would be fun having Broedrick in it, who said he was even funny... And Dr Claw is not what you would expect either.The Ferrely Brothers was at one point going to make this, and their choice was the one we all would have seen thinking of Gadget, Jim Carrey... That would of been a class film and probably a bit gross out, which for the original fan Base would of enjoyed at that point.Then Spielberg wanted to do it with Chevy Chase or Steve Martin, both again would have had the chops to pull it off... Yet what we got was a not so thought out piece of garbage. I've never met anyone who has seen the film or actually enjoyed it... and insult to the cartoons...

reviews.review_title: a movie plagued by an imposter
reviews.content: This movie sure wasn't so great.  For a theatrical release it's so underwhelming.  Kids no doubt liked it.  But adults expecting more may find it disappointing.  Curiously, no one made any big fuss about the Gadgetmobile.  It was far worse than Jar Jar Binks.  It's trying to be hip but couldn't.  A lot of jokes aren't funny enough.  You knew what would happen to the guru.  There's a scene spoofing Godzilla, but that idea was recently seen in The Lost World: Jurassic Park.  The English Patient joke was funny though. When I saw the trailer and learned the plot involves an imposter of Inspector Gadget, I had the instant feeling this may not turn out so well. It's like what happened to the movie Judge Dredd.  You barely know these characters to care about them.  The hero would have to prove what makes him great.  As it is, it's 80 minutes long to state what makes Gadget a great character.Also, what's curious is the fact that a director known only for the movie Cool as Ice gets a gig for this big budget movie.The verdict: 2.5 of 5 stars.

There are adaptions and there are remakes of cartoons. This movie straight up defiles the cartoon it was based upon. If there were a porno based up the Inspector Gadget franchise, I'd find it'd be pressed hard to be more offensive then Matthew Brodrick's performance as Inspector Gadget. To put it into perspective... there was a direct to video sequel starring French Stewart as Gadget... that was infinitely better as it least French Stewart knows how to play a bumbling idiot. It would seem rather then been watch Get Smart, The Pink Panther movers and the Original series Brodrick instead decided to watch Rob Schneider Movies as he plays Gadget as some unlucky guy were supposed feel sorry for and hope he gets the girl. This enough is more then enough to upset the fans of the original show, but that wasn't enough for the people writing this film. Dr. Claw in the original series was always hidden in the shadows, making him one of the most iconic villains for not being seen... this movie didn't even wait a half hour to give him a face... or an excuse to have the claw name by having him lose his hand in a really really stupid way along with when Joe (yeah they thought that Gadget needed a name) got his cyborg body.Penny and Brain in the original show did most of the work so that Gadget could take the credit and be a hero. Here they almost weren't even present and you can't say it was they were too afraid at the idea of cgi effects (straight up abuse in this film) given what they did with brain in the credits. Chief Quimby was played up as a straight up jerk the whole movie too.This issue I have is about a character but it gets its own point because of just how awful it was. In the cartoon Gadget near the end of the series got his "Scrappy Doo" of the time, Corporal Capeman, an obnoxious overweight man who boarders on being a vigilante but ends up extending Gadget's gross incompetence.... he would have been a welcome condition compared to what gadget got as a sidekick... namely the the gadget mobile. In the original cartoon the gadget mobile was quiet, it's most amazing feature was it was a police car that was up to racing specifications that could become a precursor to sub suv. Here they decided to turn it into an obnoxious, severely racist stereotype, wingman to Gadget. I know it was part of Disneys need to push some over the top magical character in kid's faces but It was obnoxious to some of us who were grown teens who grew up with the show and had this paste it character added.The plot follows Joe Brown as a originally a pathetic security guard hoping to become a police officer but didn't have what it takes, so one day while working guarding a science firm working on building cybernetics controlled by psionic transferring chips allowing people to control robot parts with the human brain... he interrupts a robbery by Dr. Claw and his henchmen and he gets blown up after the scientist who made the parts gets murdered but his daughter sees the effort Joe went through to try and save her dad and insists they do unethical beyond belief things to save Joe's life turning him into something looking like a cross between Robocop and the Mask.Joe becomes Inspector gadget, someone chief quimby treats like he deserves to be treated given he hasn't done anything at this point to make him more then mascot for the police force then anything. Gadget insists on trying to catch claw.At some point as if Brodricks bad acting wasn't bad enough, a robo gadget shows up built by claws henchmen... it demonstrates that brodrick can play an evil version of gadget somehow even worse then his portrayal of good gadget.Somewhere along the movie claw snaps the chip that lets gadget control his gadgets and it looks like he effectively dies... til magically he saved by his heart with the power of love or something. In the end he catches claw (can't they even get that right?) and saves the day.To say this movie was bad would be like saying wisdom tooth surgery pain is a bit achy.

The movie is very short. The story could be more elaborated and the visual effects could be less poor. However the actors can be convincent once it's a non-sense movie. If you and your kids don't have anything better to watch or to do, you can go for it, although it's better and cheaper wait for the video release. If you expect a Disney standard movie, forget it!

As soon as I saw a preview for this movie, I thought to myself that I HAD to go see it.  My husband thought it was going to be corny.  However, I'm glad I went to go see it.  (I won't give away too much in this, and I don't think there will be any spoilers.)There were a few things that were not consistent with the cartoon series, but I think that they were forgivable in most respects.  I did not like the fact that you could see Claw's face.  That just shouldn't have been.  And what about the car?  Didn't it change from a car to a mini van kind of thing?  And while we're on the subject of the car, what about the fact that it could talk?  Hmmmm...The effects weren't overdone, as some might have thought.  The previews were not as representative of the movie as I originally saw them to be.Matthew Broderick was a perfect casting choice in this; he has the mannerisms and the endearing qualities that make him the ideal Inspector.All in all, I liked the movie immensely.  This is one movie that I'm going to buy as soon as it comes out on video or DVD.  This movie is great for the kids, but for the older peoples who are expecting a lot out of it I suggest they go to another movie.  This is supposed to be fun, and since that was what I was expecting, that's what I got.  :o)

I saw this on cable last week.  I'm so glad I missed it when it was in the theater.  It was so bad that I kept thinking I should turn it off... but I had to see how much worse it could get.Even Matthew Broderick couldn't save this one.The one saving grace of this movie is that it's short.

reviews.review_title: Horrible reworking of classic kids fare
reviews.content: I was (and still am) a gigantic fan of the original cartoon series INSPECTOR GADGET, and, when I first heard of a live-action film based on the same, I was genuinely excited.  But, Hollywood being what it is, completely bungled the whole thing - yes, the characters are retained (Gadget, Penny, Brain, Claw, etc...)...but Gadget is the goofy, overrated Matthew Broderick (who has never been good in anything, he's just not strong enough an actor), Penny is a teenie-bopper wannabe, Brain hardly exists and Claw (aagh!!) we see his face!  Lots of times!  Throughout the whole movie!!!  The film is more of a spoof on the original series than any clever adaptation of it...and with such a ridiculous plot (Claw steals the technology used to "make" Gadget and creates an identical twin which is hell-bent on destroying the city), who can be blamed for being utterly disappointed?  What could have become a genuine, highly popular franchise is now doomed to the "video sequel" lot.  Give me the cartoon reruns anyday.  Rating: 4.5/10.

reviews.review_title: Don't Try To Diss This Movie Too Much
reviews.content: Okay, so this movie isn't perfect. Or terribly funny. But then again, this movie, like the show, was meant for kids, so if you plop any kid in front of this and the TV show and they're interested, try and rethink this movie. So the cinematography wasn't great and the acting had much to be desired for (Rupert Everett especially, yeesh) but that's what you kinda get for making a movie based off of a kid's show. And for all the jerkoffs who said the movie was bad because it "didn't follow the show," try watching the sequel, that movie is worse than this and really does follow the original premise the cartoon offered. So maybe Inspector Gadget wasn't meant to be made into a movie? I'll let you decide.But the answer is yes.

I just came back from the theatres and saw Inspector Gadget. I like the characters in there, especially that HOT scientist. This sure was like the cartoon back then, but it was quite different, but not too much. I liked his gears all around while fighting crime, these were so awesome. So THRILLING.

A guy will be transformed into a machine after sustaining a serious injury.A light-stuff waltdisneyan comedy based on effects,the beautiful scientist girl's smile,many runs. It has a flavour of a concept of a fight against crime where the good guy always wins.This movie lags behind the quality of 'analyze this' with a distance like earth from moon.

....couldn't rescue this picture from abject mediocrity. Michelle Trachtenberg, captured just before she scored the plum role of Dawn on "Buffy", is a prodigious young talent, but is given too little to do in this sub-par film adaptation of the "Inspector Gadget" animated series. Matthew Broderick and Rupert Everett mug shamelessly to little effect, and the end result is frankly a mess. The film is too chaotic and violent for very young children, though it might just work for pre-teens. For older viewers, there is too much cuteness (typical Disney), the acting is way too hammy and apart from the challenge of spot-the-cameo, there is not much on offer.The film pretends to be a retread of "The Six Million Dollar Man", but in fact offers a saccharine reworking of "Robocop", as bumbling but good-hearted security guard John Brown (Broderick) is horrifically injured in a robbery-murder, providing the raw material for the eponymous crime fighter. Unlike the animated series, the film emphasises Gadget (and the romantic interest, robotics expert Dr. Brenda Bradford) and plays down the importance of Gadget's niece Penny and dog Brain, who in the cartoon series did all the detective work while Gadget bumbled about, getting himself into trouble.This film also deserves some sort of award for shameless product placement. The billboard with an internet search engine prominently displayed could be forgiven, but the candy and soft drink vending machine in Gadget's car - in a children's picture - is beyond the pale. Even Robocop would baulk at this level of corporate mind control.

I admit, the movie loosely sticks to the story lines created from the animated series but it has a certain charm that todays movies lack. It has some fun and daring and not to much over the top useless violence. The death of Brenda's father is a little too much for a children's movie but the main characters need a motivation for there actions. Luke would still be on that dirt ball planet if the storm troopers didn't 86 his aunt and uncle. The effects were cool and I would like to have seen some of the deleted scenes on the DVD when it came out but all in all its a fun kids movie and should be seen as that.

Hi Im 13 Years Old And Me Being A Big Fan Of The Inspector Gadget Old Cartoon! I Liked The Movie It Was Ok It Was Funny But Not As Good As I Thought It Would Be! Inspector Gadget Is About This Man John Brown Who Gets Blowed Up By Claw And John Ends Up In In The Hospital So They Cut Him Open And Put Gears And Other Stuff In Him To Make Him Become Inspector Gadget! Enough Said... Great Special Effects! The Gadgetmobel Is Cool! From Jeremy

"Inspector Gadget" is one of the best jobs I've seen of making a movie out of a TV series, on par with the original "Addams Family".  All the main characters are back, and only two (Quimby and Claw) have changed.  The movie managed to retain it's predecessor's over-the-top goofiness without making it too dumb.There is a very good supporting cast, with Joely Fisher, Dabney Coleman, and Andy Dick.  The Claw (R. Everett) is more of a debonair character, but that's needed to make a movie.  It would have been nice for the movie to have been a bit longer, but it's worth seeing.

This is a PG rated movie, and therefore you will see some little children walking into the theater to see it.  This movie wasn't really my type.  In my personal opinion, it is the same as the television cartoon except that it has more visual effects. One thing I did enjoy is the way current technology has allowed the film creators to incorporate all the effects from the cartoon and more into this movie.  For example, you will see these cool extended arms and legs, a flying fan protruding from his hat, and etc.  It is somewhat interesting to see.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as you'd think...
reviews.content: Much changed from the excellent cartoon show, of course, but still entertaining.  There are a few really funny moments.  It suffers from Jar Jar Binks Syndrome (annoying character detracting from film, in this case a talking car), but on the whole a good movie.  "The Claw" is very funny, his characterization is perhaps the most inspired part of the movie.  Getting to see pre-Gadgetized John Brown try to save the day was entertaining as well. I can't believe Mr. Showbiz rated this at only 7% out of 100%.  I'd give it at least 62%/100%.  Without the jive-talking car, I'd give it 72%/100%.-Eric

Disney, now that it's run by CEO Michael Eisner, is REALLY losing it's touch.  I can hear what Walt would say if he saw what Eisner was doing: "What have you done to my empire?"This movie was made after Disney bought off DiC Animation City (but they're free from Eisner's clutches now) so they make a live-action movie based off one of their classic '80's 'toons, namely "Inspector Gadget".  Novel concept!And what do they do?  Disney-ify it.  Meaning: many changes are made just for the sake of changes.  I liked the Universal movie "Street Fighter" because it tried to tie in the game with news headlines of 1994.  This is just more junk, the newest brick-in-the-wall of the Disney empire. 
A "Yahoo!" billboard falls on Claw's car and we hear the tune from the commericals.  Stereotypical Asian music plays as a doctor holds up a pair of chopsticks.  This is one element of a cartoon that falls flat in live-action.  Product placements everywhere.  Skittles, McDonalds, Apple Computers, etc.  At the time this movie was in theatres, McDonald's had an "Inspector Gadget" promotion and Skittles candies gave away prizes tying in with this movie.  Shameless, huh?  All that missing was the mottos from the commericals.  Little nitpick I also found: while the cartoon took place in Metro City, this movie takes place in Riverton.  (Just wait.)  The Gadgetmobile's license plate, which is built by Brenda, reads Ohio.  But at the Gadget vs. Evil Gadget fight, doesn't the bridge they're fighting on look a lot like the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco?This film just sinks under all it's gimmicks and ads.  Nothing priceless, Walt wouldn't be proud.  After paying little homage to the cartoon (THEY SHOWED DR. CLAW'S FACE!!!  HOW DARE THEY!!!), the Gadgetmobile, during the credits, says, "This was my movie.  That's right, MY movie.  Even though we called it "Inspector Gadget"."  If they called it "The Wacky Talking Police Squad Car Movie," no one would've bought it.  It's almost like they're hinting at something.  Like this was almost another movie before the cartoon's name was slapped on it.  That's license abuse!Bottom line: Misassembled.   Go go get "The Iron Giant" instead.

reviews.review_title: It was a truly horrible movie, but...
reviews.content: I want to make a point here, first of all.  "Inspector Gadget" is not a great movie.  It's not even a remotely good movie.  In fact, it's a horrible movie, the type that knows it's insulting the audience's intelligence and gloats on this fact.  But, dang it, I laughed.  Not constantly, grant you, but enough for me to leave thinking, "That was funny."  Horrible, but still decidedly funny.Actually, "Inspector Gadget" gets fairly high honors in my book, because I'm forced to rate it as my second favorite terrible movie, the first being Tim Burton's "Mars Attacks!"  The problem was that it was funny at places, and those places were almost enough to make it a funny movie.Now, let me state the obvious.  The script is horrid.  Or maybe even worse than that.  Let me put it this way:  It's even worse than "Titanic," a lot worse.  Also, David Kellogg's direction is idiotic, over-the-top, zany, and utterly revolting.  The film stars quite a few talented figures, like Matthew Broderick and Rupert Everett, but they're all completely wasted.Still, it's funny.  What more can I really say?** out of ****.

reviews.review_title: Was this supposed to be Inspector Gadget?
reviews.content: I have never seen a good cartoon get butchered so badly. The only thing this crap has to do with the cartoon series is the names. Granted I loved Broderick in Ferris Bueller's Day Off but he is in no way shape or form good as Inspector Gadget. Penny was a teen who looked more like a sappy BSB or N'Sync fan rather than the intelligent niece. Brain was somewhat decent, just not as vocal as his cartoon counterpart. Gadget was smart in this one, not his hilarious idiotic self like he is in the cartoon. In the series, Penny and Brain always solved the case, they could have been written out of this movie totally and it would have been better. Dr. Claw was a total mistake! You never, ever saw his face in the series. The only way you could see his face was the action figure that was made of him. (which looked crappy too!)  And what about his claw?  It wasn't even a claw, it was a clamp!  Granted the metal arm and hand in the series wasn't a claw either but at least it was cool.  MADD cat in the movie was pure white, nothing like the black and grey cat we all loved and they even gave him a different name. This movie sucks and if watched (you better not spend money on it) should be considered it's own movie and not even though as having anything to do with the cartoon. This is crappity crap!P.S. - Since when did Disney get rights to Inspector Gadget

Of all the movies I've seen recently, this is probably the worst. The T.V. Series was more exciting than this! Lame jokes, boring, outdone, plot, idiotic gadgets, and more. This movie is a total waste of time for anyone to even think about watching it! Sheesh!

reviews.review_title: What a sorry excuse for a comedy
reviews.content: What in God's name was Matthew Broderick thinking?  One of the more talented actors in the industry, Broderick has, for reasons unknown, been churning out below average movies for most of the last 15 years.  Inspector Gadget is just another worthless piece of junk to add to his collection.  This movie is way too short and has way too much bad acting to be of any use to any living creature...unless you run out of fire wood.   I'm looking at a can of Sprite right now and realizing that, in fact, the can of Sprite is funnier and much more fulfilling than this movie.Unless you include Broderick's voice acting as Simba in The Lion King (1994), Election (1999) has been his only good movie since Glory (1989). Hopefully, Broderick can get out of this bad movie funk soon, because he is very fun to watch on the big screen.2 out of 10

reviews.review_title: Bad Movie! Another Terrible Cartoon to Live-Action Film Adaptation
reviews.content: Remember in the 90's when these studios were pumping out these live-action adaptations of classic animated series? Most of them were awful including this one. This was a horrible movie and a bad adaptation of the cartoon. Did the people who made this even watch the cartoon? Not only is Matthew Broderick horribly miscast as Inspector Gadget, his acting absolutely terrible and unconvincing. His performance is downright embarrassing. Dr. Claw was never shown in the cartoon we just heard his voice. In the movie we see his face and body for the entire movie. Penny was an insult. Her character was crucial in the animated series, but here she was useless and did absolutely nothing. You could cut her character out the movie and nothing vaule was lost. Michelle Tractenberg was also miscast. There was no chemistry between Matthew Broderick and love interest Joely Fisher. DL Hughley is obnoxious as the voice of the talking car. Typical jive talking black guy. The movie is poorly directed, goofy sound effects, it's not funny, and the movie was wayyyy too short! This movie is only 1 hour and 10 minutes and that's not including the end credits.... This movie stinks! Just watch the original animated series from the 80's.

Sorry -- this one wasn't funny for me, nor my 8-year old son or 7-year old daughter. Much like "Wild Wild West", this movie suffers from too much money spent on too many techo-tricks and not enough money saved for better story and/or character development. I swear that on at least one occasion, Matthew Broderick gave the camera one of those 'deer in the headlights' takes, saying "don't blame me folks, I'm just earning a couple of mil doing really expensive sights gags".

a so-so film. the plot is very straightforward, and the story whizzes past you as fast as you can you can say "go-go gadget chopper!" - a very fast-paced film. there are some laugh-out-loud moments, and rupert everett makes a very suave Dr. Claw! i can't say anything brilliant about this movie- being a fan of the cartoon as a child, i was expecting more. this movie will go down better with the young'uns.

reviews.review_title: A movie not should of been funny, but wasn't
reviews.content: I'm not quite sure why, but this movie just doesn't play the way it should. It should be humerous and fun, but instead is just boring.  I think a large part of it is because they way over played the "gadgets."  The old cartoon it is based on is much better.3/10

reviews.review_title: This movie should be on Ritalin!
reviews.content: Since I  never saw the original cartoon series I had no preconceived notions of how this picture should turn out. After viewing it, I must say that it is the most frantically paced movie I have ever seen. Characters and plot twists are introduced so rapidly it is hard to take a breath. This is yet another F/X laden movie(although some of the effects are good). Rupert Everett has a way of making even the lamest lines sound halfway amusing and the gag about famous movie and TV sidekicks with their own support group is pretty good..but it comes halfway through the final credits.

I took my kids (aged 7 & 5) for a day at the movies without their mom. I was expecting the movie to be one the kids might like but I brought headphones for myself just in case the Mariner baseball game broadcast turned out to be more interesting. I was surprised that I enjoyed it. It was fast paced and the special effects were pretty good. The movie was short (90 minutes I think) and they kept the slow romantic parts to a minimum so the kids wouldn't get bored. I thought it was pretty funny and the kids had a good laugh. I give it a seven out of ten.

reviews.review_title: Adaptation not completely bad but neither faithful to the original
reviews.content: The idea of making a movie on the character of cartoons the Inspector Gadget didn't seem completely bad and it could be quite amusing... but at the end the movie is a true entertainment (for the children) but it is not completely original to the series, the blame has it the script and certain characterizations of some characters.   	Matthew Broderick didn't make a bad performance like the Inspector Gadget. Michelle Trachtenberg neither was not well completely as Penny, the Inspector Gadget's niece. Although Brain the dog instead of having been a real dog could have been a dog made with CGI effects like in Scooby-Doo, I believe that it had been this way more similar to the cartoon character.  	In the movie we can finally see him the face to the Dr. Claw, but Ruppert Everett was not the most suitable actor to make of the Inspector Gadget's eternal enemy, it was not a good performance certainly. We also see that the Inspector's boss appears Gadget that, contrarily to the cartoons, it doesn't trust the Inspector Gadget when carrying out the missions. We also see that the Inspector Gadget's car speak and it is also aesthetically contrary to the car of the series of cartoons. It is not very well the character of the mayoress of Riverton, besides a painful performance it seems that the character is a little stupid. Separated, in the movie they have been allowed to incorporate a new character (the doctor Brenda Bradford), of which the Inspector falls in love Gadget, so that the main character doesn't seem a group of screws and nuts but rather he is a human being, the idea it is not bad but I eat we already know it is a typical element of Disney in his movies.   	In short that the movie is amusing, the children can love it but to some that they loved the series of cartoons they can feel enough defrauded with the movie.

reviews.content: The idea of making a movie on the character of cartoons the Inspector Gadget didn't seem completely bad and it could be quite amusing... but at the end the movie is a true entertainment (for the children) but it is not completely original to the series, the blame has it the script and certain characterizations of some characters.
