In short that the movie is amusing, the children can love it but to some that they loved the series of cartoons he/she can feel enough defrauded with the movie.

Anyone who was a fan of the original TV show will probably get a kick out of Disney's big screen version. Granted, those loyal to the cartoon will pick it apart for not sticking true on some key Inspector Gadget details (which I won't mention here due to possible spoiler - e-mail me if you want details). Storyline eventually stuck true to the `toon, after a lot of side detail and back story. The visual effects were very well placed, meaning they were not overdone or exploited for the sake of mindless entertainment.Overall, I liked it enough to see it again.

The cartoon was amazing. well, TMNT and Ghostbusters were better so i'll say that it was great, not amazing. But it was a FAR cry better than this trash. I expected this movie to be excellent, since it was made by the same director of the Vanilla Ice hit single, Cool as Ice. and fortunately, it surpassed by expectations.dont watch unless all the other bad movies and good movies and average movies in the video store are out.

I regrettably have to agree with everyone who hated this movie. I was expecting a fun time but this was boring and bad. Joely Fisher was good (but unecessary), I liked the effects, and that big glass building is awesome! Other than that...bad...just bad! My only consolation is that I watched it on tv instead of paying for it in a theatre. The trailer is way better!Gonna give it a 2
Good movie. I've watched it since it came out, when I was 3. I think the movie is better than the tv series.

reviews.review_title: The film Dr. Forester didn't have the heart to beam onto the SOL
reviews.content: Let me get one thing straight from the start. I loved 'Inspector Gadget' as a kid. Since then I have had other interests, but I still remember it well. As many other reviewers have written, THIS IS NOT INSPECTOR GADGET! Also as you might have heard, you actually SEE Claw. When I was younger I was terrified of Dr. Claw. Now he's just the guy from 'My Best Friend's Wedding' with a metal hand. Although, sad as it sounds, Rupert Everett is the only cast member who looks like he's having fun. The special FX are pretty good, due in most part to Stan Winston Studios and Dream Quest Images ( it's interesting to see how far they've come since their 'Nightmare on Elm Street' days, if only in a better movie). There are some clever moments in here, but they could easily be fit into a comercial. It's very sad to hear Don Adams was in this. To me, he is the ONLY Inspector Gadget. I've said it before and I'll say it again, Disney is the most evil force on the planet.

I think the old folks didn't like coz they hoped it to portray the comics they used to read for years, even decades.I think they don't have some basic understandings of story telling in a 100 min movie which ppl. goes to enjoy in a hall, spending quite some bucks, AND a leisurely comic series that ppl reads in a morning daily, as a bonus/supplement.The topic of this review is not the art of film making, so I just wanna say there could be lots of difference in an adaptation. I have gone through these reviews and found most of the grievances baseless.A small example: Do u think ppl. ud like to see such catastrophic surgery just due to sleeping on banana peels? Whats wrong in changing the script to make it more appealing for a film? They also forgot the movie was being made in kids in 1999, and the story was 20 years old.Please understand that its a fresh movie, not a sequel. The director has the right to take many changes in any adaptation of a story, and for legitimate reason. But in a sequel, he SHOULD NOT make any (which happened to IG2).I feel the casting, direction, comic content, SFX/ VFX all are really fine and blended perfectly to suit the sci-fi-comedy theme of the movie.I always liked Rupert in his role as Klaw - perfect for the villain needed against our hero.Bottom line: Disney had adapted, refined the story. And it worked. Whats wrong in there?

I really wanted to like this movie - the location shots were mostly filmed in Pittsburgh and the trailer had some wonderful photography.  But, even for a filmed cartoon, it was a really badly-made movie.   The continuity and pacing were both simply awful.   The best bits in the movie are under the ending credits, so it's (almost) worth sticking it out to the end (though, oddly, it does pick up a little over the last half hour or so).When the best performance in a movie is by Andy Dick, you know there's got to be a problem...

reviews.review_title: This Movie Is Worth a View
reviews.content:
I think Disney did a great job with this movie.  I had expected it to be of a lesser quality.  However, Matthew Broderick did a good job of playing the nieve, yet heroic Inspector Gadget.  Again, better than I had expected.
WARNING: SMALL SPOILERS FROM THIS POINT!I did have a couple of regrets about the movie, though. (This has mainly to do with living up to the cartoon.  The movie by itself is great, nontheless.)  For one, they didn't get Penny and Brain as involved as I thought they might have.  I guess the GadgetMobile kind of stole some of that supporting-actor thunder.  Also, I was somewhat dissappointed that they made almost no effort to hide Dr. Claw's face and overall appearance.  It would have been cool to see them do clever things to hide his face, a la Wilson on "Home Improvement" or Ms. Bellum on "The Powerpuff Girls."  In addition, they didn't have the cat-face logo for Dr. Claw. Also, I feel that they failed to fully capture the "Get Smart"-esque feel of Inspector Gadget's character.Of course, this isn't to take away from the movie, which is excellent by all other standards.It was interesting to see how they used the CGI for the different gadgets, etc.SPOILERS OVER!Overall, I'd say that this movie is worth the time to see.  A good live-action translation of the cartoon series, despite the petty details earlier mentioned.

I caught this movie on TV the other day and was absolutely amazed by Kellog's creative movie-adaption of this 80's cartoon. And I was no lesser impressed by Matthew Broderick's acting (as usual). Ok, so it's a children's movie. And it's Disney. But with all the funny references and jokes, it's a hilarious movie also for people over the age of eleven. This is a movie you shouldn't have to miss. And it won't take you long to catch it either cause it's (unfortunately) under 90minutes long. And be sure to sit tight during the credits:)I give this movie a ****/***** considering it's genre and what's expected of it. Don't get me wrong, it's not a masterpiece, but it's a great movie where you get what you're supposed to get.

reviews.review_title: If there was a movie God, this movie would have never been made as is!
reviews.content: If you enjoy seeing what must have started as a 2 hour movie in unconnected bursts of unwatchability, you'll love this film. Otherwise, you'll just wonder how they could have made such a film from something so simple to translate to the big screen as Inspector Gadget.In the previews for the film, many scenes were shown which were not in the film, and within the film, some scenes just don't make sense. While the movie is slightly less than 1 hour and a half, I can only think of one truly memorable moment, and that is just before or during the credits!

This movie is a fun movie to watch. It is no piece of masterfulcinema, but, for its intended audience, kids- the movie is good.Although the movie includes the basic characters from theanimated series and the same basic principles. It does, howeverdeviate from the original strip for the movie-goer purpose. Mainly,the Inspector's love interest, and the wise cracking car.
I don't know what all these people are thinking, but the ratingshould certainly be higher than a 4, the same as Howling V: TheRebirth. Please.......Good movie. 7/10

reviews.review_title: Kids might like it, if there's nothing else on.
reviews.content:
Disappointing. The characters in the film all sound like they're reading their lines from teleprompters hidden just offscreen, though the local news anchor usually does a better job of that. The guy who does the Gadgetmobile voice is probably the most energetic performer of the bunch (until he starts to get on your nerves), and we never see him. For a comedy based on a screwball cartoon (which, in turn, was based loosely on the old "Get Smart!" TV show) it's all pretty stilted and flat, almost like the actors knew that it wasn't going to be funny and were anxious to just get it over with.
The self-referential ("Gosh, it's all like some kind of silly cartoon!") lines are amusing at first, but when the actors start winking and nodding their way through every other joke it all begins to sounds a little desperate.Less demanding kids might enjoy this movie, but there are lots of others that both you and your kids would enjoy much more.

reviews.review_title: Not terrible, but certainly below average.
reviews.content: Overall, I thought this film was below average, even for a Disney kids' movie.  I love the cartoon "Inspector Gadget."  Unfortunately, I thought this film was a cheap hack of a vehicle mainly used to promote products like Coke and Skittles.  (As it is, in the theatre I'm already sick of being shown commercials before the trailers.  This isn't television, dangit; didn't I *pay* for this?  Why weren't these ads booed away like they were in the 80's the last time the theatres tried this?)  And why is it only 70 minutes from Disney logo to roll credits?As an adult, I found the Gadget movie to be tedious in many places and largely lacking development.  The slapstick humor, such as when Gadget accidentally grabs a man's crotch, generally did not make me smile even a little.  However, I can see how this kind of humor would appeal to children.I enjoyed some of the gags, like the "Minions Anonymous" bit, but if this were an adult movie, I would have been hard-pressed to give it a 3 because of the annoyingly overt product placement and the repeated direct address of the audience with references to Disney.  (Not to mention my disappointment since the cartoon Gadget was so superior.)  Disney has produced much better movies.Rating this as a kid's movie, and considering the aforementioned issues, I gave it a 4.

reviews.review_title: Possibly better left for the kiddies....
reviews.content:
I generally see about 70 to 75 movies a year and some of those include films that are probably more aimed at a much younger age group. However, in many of these type of films I can usually find enough to keep me entertained.
And Inspector Gadget had me hooked for about the first half hour but then without the help of an engaging plot, my interest began to wane. The tricks and gadgets that the Inspector (Matthew Broderick) is constantly pulling seemed to me to get a little repetitious after a while.
Joely Fisher makes a very bright and effervescent screen presence. Much more than I can remember in any of her previous films. And Rupert Everett, as Claw, the Inspector's nemesis, is a hoot. He plays the bad guy very, very broadly and is so different than any other role I have seen him in that it is hard to believe it is actually Everett in the role.
I can't say I am sorry I went to the movie, but it really didn't live up to my expectations. I would give it about a 6 on a scale of 10.

reviews.review_title: From the perspective of my 7-year-old so... He loved it!
reviews.content: From the 7-yr-old...  I'm a big "Gadget" fan and I loved this movie!Now a word from Daddy who saw it with him...  The movie has pretty good flow to it.  Disney was kind enough to include many private chuckles for the parents.  One note...  Don't leave the theatre prior to the end of the credits.  The out-takes include a bit that reminds us of movie villains from the past... Very funny.  Personally, I thought Broderick & Fisher did a nice job, but Rupert Everett seems to think that Gadget is still a cartoon.  The exaggerated facial expressions were a bit much to bear.

reviews.review_title: So terrible that I tried to get my money back.
reviews.content: This is one of those movies you think that the makers would refuse to release it because it is so terrible. Obviously they were thinking that children are stupid and are excellent for absorbing endless ads and would think they are entertainment because it is slapstick funny. What is it with the talking car with buttons that say Wendy's, McDonalds, M&M's and Skittles? There was no talking car in the cartoon. (Dr.) Claw is supposed to be evil, not handsome and charming. Why is Rupert Everet 'Claw' anyway? Were the writers on drugs when they wrote these scenes? It looks like they were (badly) lampooning Robo Cop, with the turning a man into a crime fighting android thing. I tried to get my money back but there was a policy where if I watch more than 30 minutes of a movie, you don't get a refund. I'm sorry I watched more than 30 minutes of that pile of crap. After I was told the no-refund policy, I decided to watch the rest of the hideous garbage called Inspector Gadget.

I'm truly torn about this movie.  While parts of it were very funny......it really wasn't Gadget.  Having grown up on the cartoon....I missed Quimby getting blown up...and Penny's book....and Where the HECK was MAD?  Making "Claw"(another wincer) a businessman was just a bad idea.Matthew Broderick was at least likable, and The two best touches in the movie:  Don West's voice, and the henchmen meeting.

reviews.review_title: boring, but good for little children I guess
reviews.content: A typical slapstick comedy, but lacking creativity, so mostly not funny. It's short and simple, good for the kiddies, but I don't recommend it for anyone else.  I found it interesting that women were stereotyped as airheaded and men as evil or spineless.

This film for some reason has been entirely underrated. It is a remake of the old 80's cartoon I used to watch as a small boy. I loved every gadget he had. For anybody who liked the cartoon, this shouldn't be a disappointment! It is just like the cartoon only the characters are real now. Also, to give it spice, they gave it a remarkable score, by John Debney, with touches of that familiar old cartoon score. The music has almost as much of an action feel as the movie does! To bad the score isn't available on CD!The CGI is seamless. This is one of the few films where the special effects don't look like they are done by CGI!!! I'm not knocking other films with CGI by any means, but in this particular film I think Dream Quest Images have out done themselves!The acting is A+++. Rupert Everett, is remarkably funny as Claw, his facial expressions will have you rolling on the ground in laughter.Matthew Broderick is also funny as the Inspector Gadget.....just watch as he first discovers about his new abilities!Great movie, all the way. It is a must see. If you get it on DVD, you get 2 times as much of the fun, and the picture quality is wonderful!  An action packed film filled with fun, fun, fun. Remarkable!

Inspector Gadget was a great movie.  And luckily they used the same "Inspector Gadget" theme song that was in the cartoon.  I like how in the beginning they show how John Brown became Inspector Gadget and how Dr. Claw got his claw.  The only thing that I didn't like was the girl that played Penny. I liked the end when Don Adams(the voice of the cartoon "Inspector Gadget") was the voice of Brain.

Well, another Disney... I'm 25 and i still remember when they did GREAT stuff. Walt is dead, long live whoever is CEO:(IG is a nice movie in general. The special effects are top-notch, the story is"       ", Matthew is better than average and there are anuff clichés to bring any story down to ridicule.It has it's funny momments but it could be better with a story. With time, Disney will start to hire good story writers again and all will be better cause you have to make movies for the movies, not the stock market...
My friends and i watched this together and laughed our asses off. Tbh its not a "good" movie but still had fun
My god, what have I just watched?!? Such an abomination, I'm in shock! So, so bad on every level.

Zero substance and mediocre acting make this "movie" more suited to Saturday morning television than a big screen.  Subtracting the protracted animated screws intro and  credits, Gadget registers barely an hour.  Someone at Disney must have cut out the scenes that would have made for a feature film.Be sure to watch this number before spending a dime on it.  I taped it off cable and now regret the waste of space.

OK.  I think the TV show is kind of cute and it always has some kind of lesson involved.  So, when my kids decided they wanted to see this movie, I decided to tag along.  I wish I'd stayed home and watched the TV show instead.The fact that the humor is silly and unoriginal is the least of the problems with this movie.  The plot is next to non-existant, the characters seem to exist in a vacuum, and, worst of all, Gadget does not carry any lesson whatsoever.  It appears that Disney took all of the things that make Inspector Gadget work on TV and tossed them all.  To be fair, my younger child (8 years old) liked the movie but the older one (10 years old) came away thinking it silly (he was too old for the youth humor but too young for any of the adult humor).Generally, I like Disney films but this one misses by a mile.  It is OK for a very narrow age band (say 7 to 9) but a must miss for everybody else.

reviews.review_title: A Very Bad Re-Make Of A very Good Cartoon
reviews.content: This movie, was one of the stupidest i have ever seen. I was bored the entire time I sat in the theatre. Although I love Matthew Broderick and Rupert Everett, I heartily disliked this film.

reviews.review_title: A feature film made for TV?
reviews.content: INSPECTOR GADGET is neither a turkey nor a swan.  Call it -- hmmm, maybe a robin.It's hard to figure out how a movie with so many gadgets and SFX (and the effects are actually pretty good) could turn out so thoroughly bland, but GADGET manages it.  "Bland" certainly describes Matthew Broderick's performance, which energizes only when he's playing his evil robot double. Joely Fisher and Michelle Trachtenberg are a little livelier as scientist Brenda Bradford and Gadget's niece Penny -- but not much.The writing is bland, too, with more classic-Disney platitudes than any live-action Disney comedy has used in decades.  There are rare moments when it develops a faint sparkle, mostly when it's breaking the fourth wall (the Gadgetmobile remarks partway through on this being a Disney movie), but nobody's really made an effort to put any sort of spin on the standard hero-girl-evil genius plot.  What saves it from utter boredom are the gadgets, which are consistently crisp, inventive, and used to very good effect.Truth is, though, that this isn't really a theatrical feature film; it's a Wonderful World of Disney TV-movie that someone has accidentally released to the big screen.

With the seemingly endless accessories and gadgets at their disposal, this film relies on lame writing. Gadget's car could have been a source of scene-stealing hilarity, but poor writing and weak delivery shut that off. Matthew Broderick does a good turn in his dual role.

reviews.review_title: Broderick & Special Effects Steal The Show!!
reviews.content: I took my five-year-old son to see this movie and he had trouble staying in his seat!!  With lots of action and special effects to keep the show moving, Matthew Broderick plays the perfect (but bumbling) Inspector Gadget.  I enjoyed it, too, (I'm 42, but still a kid-at-heart) because there were some subtle insertions of mild "adult-oriented" humor along with some good one-liners and dialog by Broderick and D.L. Hughley (the voice of Gadgetmobile).

reviews.review_title: Buy stuff! It will make you happy!
reviews.content: I remember Inspector Gadget from when I was young, but he doesn't hold a special place in my heart. So liberty-taking is not the reason I don't like this film. Mainly it's because of the relentless product placement. It's like watching a really long advert. This would be bad enough if it wasn't a children's film. Children can't reason against propaganda. Also you'd think an English actor of Rupert Everett's calibre would have been able to point out to someone that phrases like "myriad of" are grammatically horrible and sound moronic. For these two reasons, if you let your children watch this, you are a bad parent.Another thing is the Comedy Black Man, the Uncle Tom type, which has become a massive cliché in films over recent years, and which I find really annoying. It's a pity, because without these things (which admittedly would make the film about 15 minutes long) it would have been really fun.

Where do I start?  This is a fun movie.  Ok, that'll work.  I enjoyed it enough.  The special effects were not just well-done, but funny too. Normally, when I hear the term "family movie"  I tend to think "kids movie". Well, that is kinda the case in this movie, but it's not too cheezy for those of us mature non-children.  The biggest problem is that the whole movie rushes by you in about 80 minutes.  Now, if you're paying 5 bucks for the movie ticket, you're only getting 9.6 seconds to the penny.  That's about one computer-animated gadget, two lines of dialogue, and a laugh or two.  Not bad.  Bottom line:  If you're taking the kids, they'll love it, and maybe you will too.

People say it's not a movie for adults. I beg to differ. There's just enough witty double entendre between Rupert and Andy to amuse the gay audience (as one of that audience, I laughed quite hand/claw extensions, and of course the kids did not). That is what is interesting about the film -- there's a little bit of humor for adults that would not make parents not take their kids if they are overly protective about that sort of thing (because it will just go over their heads). My secret suspicion about why they showed Claw's face even though you never see it in the original cartoon is that some closet case at Disney just really, really enjoyed looking at Rupert

reviews.review_title: Not much to this film, except for product placements
reviews.content: What a disappointment this one turned out to be. The story was only moderately interesting (even to my nine-year-old nephew). It had the same formula as most other kids' movies out there, without the charm of some of the better ones.I guess I couldn't get past the terrible product placements throughout the movie.  I go to the movies for entertainment, not to be subjected to 90 minutes of advertising.  I usually love Disney movies, but this one did nothing for me.Too bad, because I liked the idea of an Inspector Gadget film.  I had only seen a few episodes of the original, but it seemed to have a similar flavour.  The effects were interesting and convincing, but not enough to rescue the movie, which wasn't clever enough to appeal to adults.I can only go as far as 5 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: My view on the movie version of Inspector Gadget
reviews.content: I was worried that it wouldn´t be a good remake, but very soon I saw some parallels to the cartoon. Actually it just got better by being made into a motion picture. And the reason is that the two brains behind the cartoon have been used as consults and producers. The movie will be better if you saw the cartoon during the 80´s. Go,Go,Gadget

What's the deal with Disney movies lately?   I mean, the live action ones. Okay, even the animated movies are losing its luster.   With that said, Inspector Gadget has got to be the worst live action Disney movie to date (or at least of the ones I seen).  What happen to all the TRON's and MIDNIGHT MADNESS'S?Where shall I begin?   Let's start with the over commercialisation of the movie in general.  Was the blatant Yahoo reference supposed to be funny? It would have been less insulting if the movie just paused for a commercial break.  And I think I had enough of Disney slapping their name into the script (i.e. the car nonchalantly says "...this is a Disney movie...").
Now let's move on to the utter disrespect for the traditions the cartoon set.  The car NEVER talked (this is not Knight Rider) and Dr. Claw was NEVER seen.   I admit they got the other mundane details right but the visible Dr. Claw just made it so detached from it's cartoon roots.
Trust me when I say you'll get more enjoyment by watching re-runs of the old Inspector Gadget cartoons instead of sitting through this special effect dreck.

reviews.review_title: Robocop for kids? It only gets worse...
reviews.content: If you're like me, the idea of a "Disnified" version of Robocop makes your cringe. But here it is! Inspector Gadget is based on the TV show of the same name, it once again shows that some things don't translate to film very well. Don't get me wrong, I used to love the cartoon. But this movie just didn't capture the feel. I also noticed that it was a little violent for a Disney movie. Once again, taking a page from Robocop! Plus, I didn't like the casting really. Matthew Broderick does a believable job, but he just isn't my vision of Inspector Gadget! Plus, I didn't really like the fact that they showed Dr. Claw's (oh I'm sorry... "Claw's") face. Bottom line: Good movie? Not really. Worth a look? Sure, you can see what I mean...

I just saw the movie yesterday, and I expected it to be fairly funny, and a little childish for me, but I ended up loving it! It was very funny, and not just for little kids. The different gadgets that Inspector Gadget has helps the movie be funny, but also has a lot of other humor! I really liked it! I'll probably go see it again.

reviews.review_title: Fans of the cartoon series, don't expect much
reviews.content: I saw this movie with my little brother, since both of us loved the cartoon series.  Now granted, it does have its good points.  The special effects were great, and staying along the lines of the original theme music was definitely a good idea.  The bad parts of this movie almost all came from the fact that the movie bore very little resemblance to the cartoon.  For one thing, Matthew Broderick is not a bad actor, but this just wasn't a good part for him.  I mean, he didn't even try to do the voice right!  The bumbling, incompetent, extremely self-confident Inspector Gadget from the cartoon was way more funny.  Dr. Claw was a disappointment too.  How can he not be, when they replace a scary, mysterious person with a sniveling little wimp?  Penny and Brain and the Mad Agents being missing in action wasn't a good idea either.  They made for the entire plot of the cartoon.  There was too much romance and confusing plot development and not enough humor.  The worst part of this movie though?  The Gadgetmobile, hands down.  With a personality at least as obnoxious as those of Jar-Jar Binks and Scrappy-Doo, I still can't see what the writers were thinking when they came up with that.  Take away Gadget's voice and personality, Dr. Claw's voice and personality, the antics of Penny and Brain, and the antics of the Mad Agents, and there goes all the humor that really made that series what it was.  If they do remake this movie or make a sequel, I sincerely hope that they think more of the fans of the cartoon.  To me, this movie seemed like it was written by people who absolutely hated the cartoon and thought they could improve it.  Well they didn't.

I watched this movie because I really like the cartoon series, but soon I had to realize that this movie can't compete with the humor of the cartoon. Much of the jokes in the cartoon are based upon Gadgets stupidity and his completely unawareness of this, but Broderick plays that character just floppy and so naive that sometimes he reminded me more of a care bear than Inspector Gadget.OK, there are some nice jokes within this movie (especially the reference to Godzilla) and it's a nice kids comedy, but if you know the original it's just disappointing.So, if you like the cartoon stay away from this movie, but if you're looking for a nice, nonsense film to watch with your kids it may be a good choice.

First off, to cover myself, this review may contain spoilers for this movie. While I don't think I reveal too much about the story or anything, I want to make sure I don't ruin it for anyone.Okay, this movie is EXACTLY what I expected.  I was a huge fan of the cartoon (and of Get Smart as well) as a young child, and had some hopes for this film.  I expected the kid stuff, it is, after all, a Disney movie, but that was outweighed by the thrill of seeing the Inspector himself in live action.  I felt that the time I spent on this movie was well worth it, as it brought back the fun I remembered about the series.  My comments below may seem a little on the harsh side, but I DID like the movie, I just have a tendency to see where I think things could have been done better.First off, the praise.  The special effects were pretty seamless and entertaining, put in where they should be, but the cinematography was wonderful!  The atmosphere in any given scene is exactly what it should be. Especially of note is the scene toward the beginning with Claw's limo being chased by Brown.  The lighting and camera angles are just what they should be.  The sets deserve just as much commendation.  The "modern" looking city was just enough cartoonish to fit with the movie, but not so much as to be unbelievable.The casting was pretty much on target.  Matthew Broderick provided a well enough Gadget, however he needed a little more development.  He goes from champion of justice to bumbling idiot just a little to quickly.  These aspects should have been blended a little more.  Rupert Everett played a perfectly diabolical Claw, but where was his CLAW?  Not this robot grasping thing he has here, but the metal glove CLAW?Now I come to Andy Dick.  What happened there?  Andy Dick, usually a very exuberant and fun actor suddenly becomes understated?  I ask, why?  His role provided some laughs, but not nearly enough as there should have been.  He should have been allowed to cut loose.  Well, there's always the sequel.Everyone else does a pretty good job, though, with the little material they had.  Dabney Coleman and Cheri Oteri needed way more screen time than they got, as their's were the most enjoyable characters.  Michelle Trachtenberg played Penny very well, but her role as the one who always saves Gadget from his own idiocy wasn't there as it should have been.  In fact, I can't think of anything really important she did to influence the finale (except for the Minions Anonymous scene).  Joely Fisher did a good job, but the Robo version of her was unnecessary.  And, of course, Rene Auberjonois is always fun to see (Odo from DS9 for non-Trekkies).Okay, now down to the REAL complaints.  The Gadgetmobile.  At the very least, its screentime should have been cut by two-thirds.  D.L. Hughley was not the right choice for the voice either.  In my opinion, THIS is where Don Adams should have been, not in a ten-second scene during the credits.  I get upset just thinking of the jokes that would have been possible between Broderick and Adams as the Gadgetmobile.  Alas, that was not to be.  Also, the CGI figure that represented the GM on the dashboard should have been eliminated, along with the literally blinking headlights.  In fact, unless Adams was there, the GM should have been eliminated altogether.Length.  An hour and eighteen minutes just doesn't cut it.  The movie should have been expanded and more screentime given to the costars of the TV show, namely Penny, Brain, and Chief Quimby.Plot.  Not enough.  Tell us WHY Claw wants these armies of Robomen!  His net worth is over 10 billion dollars, so what can these Roboguys do for him that 10 billion smackers can't?  The Robo-Gadget.  Good idea, but maybe should have been toned down in terms of cuteness.  He should have been a tad more menacing.  And how in the world did Gadget come back to life without that chip thingie?  I don't buy that.  I think Andy Dick's character got him a new one and Gadget was faking being dead to get a kiss.The jokes, and a lot of the movie overall, were too much on the kiddy side. Movies can be made that appeal to adults and kids.  Disney themselves proved this with Toy Story and it's worthy sequel.  Some of that cross-generational humor could have been well used here.Overall, as a prequel to the TV series, this wasn't too bad.  If you liked the old show, check it out.  The flaws can be overlooked if you try hard enough.  Anyway, like I said above, there's always the sequel.Go-Go Gadget!

reviews.review_title: Go watch the preview not the movie
reviews.content: This was a movie with great potential, but that was it.All the special effects were in the preview, the plot was week and character shallow. Some of the acting was superb.I was especially disapointed to see Claw's face.If you want a qick (one hour 20 minuite) quick movie, rent this but do not expect to much.

This had the potential to be a great kids movie, but the comedy and huge array of gadgets from the cartoon series, didn't make the cross-over to the motion picture business. What should have been a special FX laden comedy, turned out to be a poor and meaningless story that only a child under five would slightly enjoy, and no disrespect is intended on the five-year-olds of this world.Stay at home, turn the cartoon on and watch the Gadget Go,Go.

With its plotless frenzy and digitized incoherence, "Inspector Gadget" represents the lowest in dumb summer "fun."  Sure, "The Wild Wild West" was an expensive, joyless fiasco, but at least it FELT like a movie.  "Inspector Gadget" plays more like a commercial for the fast-food tie-in for a movie. Matthew Broderick, equally helpless in 3 different roles, takes a major step back from his brilliant, "grown-up" performance in this year's "Election."

reviews.review_title: Must see for Gadget fans and fun lovers everywhere.
reviews.content: This movie was an excellent adaption of the extremely popular cartoon series that I and many others grew up with.  Matthew Broderick, as always, did a stunning job and all others cast were perfect for the roles created or adapted for them.  Very good movie to take the kids to see, witty dialogue and humor enjoyable by any age group, if you don't laugh at least as hard as the children in the theater, I feel very sorry for you and your sense of humor.  Broderick's antics and mannerisms are very like the original character of Inspector Gadget, and provide hilarious entertainment to all ages.  Also several surprise guest appearances that can be appreciated by older TV and movie fanatics.

reviews.review_title: Good reasons to stay away from this film.
reviews.content: It was a sad day at Disney when they released this one.  Even the incredibly talented Matthew Broderick and Rupert Everett could not save it.  The plot was nonexistent and the humor was pitiful.  The high-tech special effects were apparently supposed to make this film a blockbuster, but were not very successful.  Younger kids would like this, but certainly not anyone with a little taste.

reviews.review_title: Inspector Gadget made me wanna gag!!!!
reviews.content: I saw Inspector Gadget today and too say the least I was not impressed. I don't understand why it seems lately that every cartoon that was ever slightly popular is being made into a film. It seems more of these cartoon movies bomb than make it. Are writers today so uninspired that everything they come up with is either at one time a cartoon or a TV sitcom? I loved Inspector Gadget as a child. It was one of my favorite cartoons,but this was a bad representation of it. For one thing,one of the really cool things about the cartoon was we never got to see Claw's face and throughout this whole movie his face is shown. Maybe it was intended to be more of a kid movie and that's why it couldn't hold my interest,but I wouldn't suggest wasting your time.

A lot of people underestimate this movie and judge it because it's not "exactly" like the cartoon version. You need to look at it from a different mind and openenly instead of watching it while comparing it to the cartoon.This movie had a great story line and the writing was perfect. Kids LOVE this movie, because it mixes in humour, with cool gadgets, a bad guy, a damsel and of course the hero that we all know and love. It has a great balance of everything you need for a great family movie.I wish this movie would've gotten greater reviews but I guess for those that don't have an imaginary open mind [ or kids ] can't appreciate everything that this movie brings.I'd give a ten out of ten.

reviews.review_title: Definitely worth seeing for all ages.
reviews.content: My wife and I, and our kids, aged 6 and 9, found much to delight us all in this film. The kids, of course, loved all the action and special effects. My wife and I were kept laughing by all the "in" jokes and familiar gags from years past.I won't spoil, but be sure and listen to the pages in the hospital scenes, and try and see how many characters you can identify in one of the final scenes. You'll know which one when you see it.Broderick was well-cast as the Inspector, and the other main characters were simply too cliché for words. This one *will* be a video purchase for us!

The movie was very cute and humorous. However, I was very dissappointed that it did not follow the cartoon! Penny played a VERY crucial part in the cartoon, as opposed to barely on camera in the movie. What happened to Penny's cool power book that could do anything? And her radio watch (which was only shown at the end, what is that!), and her communication with Brain. These were the best parts of the cartoon in the 80's! In this new version, Penny is just a silly little niece who plays a minimal part, and Brain is simply a dog there for posterity. True, the special effects were very amusing (however not as extensive as the previews made them appear to be), but very poorly used. The talking gadgetmobile was just ridiculous. Was this supposed to make up for Penny's lack of technology? The "cool" and "jazzy" car seemed like just a space filler in a poorly planned movie, and the work of some bored animators. Those FX were trivial compared the things being done today. Another wonderful memory of the cartoon is the exploding missions and the chief getting blown up! That was great! Unfortunately, there was nothing even remotely similar in the movie! HIGHLY DISSAPPOINTING. The movie seemed to be created as a cute little love-story "date movie" instead of a cartoon turned movie. And it was a cute "date movie" that had the girl I took to see it saying "awww" by the end. So all in all, it was a decent movie. I do not think it was worth the $16 I had to pay for my date and I to see it in the movies though.

That's about all you can say about it.As an adult, the movie lacked storyline, character, interesting dialogue, and adequate casting.  The casting of Matthew Broderick was a mistake.  I don't blame Broderick, but either he or the directing of him was atrocious.That being said, my two (almost three) year old loved it.  As did his eight and six year old cousins.The movie follows recent Hollywood formula.  Take a well-like cartoon/comic-strip character, make it live action with as many useless special effects as possible.  In other words, film a concept because you can do it.So why did I give it a relatively high '5' rating ?Simple.  How many movies can you take your kid to today, have him/her enjoy it, and not have to explain or wish away any scenes or dialogue ?

This makes a perfect companion to Mr. Magoo....both films adapted from a tv series, and both are unbelievably horrible.  Exactly twice did i laugh in "Inspector Gadget".  Plus it doesn't even follow the Gadget format!  Showing Dr. Claw's face??  All in all it's only for those who want to torture themselves.

reviews.review_title: This lifeless, humourless film is nothing more than a smelly piece of cheese
reviews.content: Go Go Gadget Cheese.Last night I watched Inspector Gadget, Disney's live action re-make of the 80's Saturday morning cartoon.  Yes, yes, I can see you all groaning and shaking your heads.  What did I expect, mutter some of you, Citizen Kane? Well, no - my expectations going into the film were not that high - but there was no way I could have realized that it was going to be *that* bad (and I've seen Wing Commander, so I _know_ bad).John Brown(Mathew Broderick) is an inept, yet well meaning security gaurd who dreams of becoming a hero.   Dr. Brenda Bradford(Joely Fisher) is a scientist working with her father to perfect a new form of cybernetics. Sanford Scolex(Rupert Everett) is the evil head of a multinational corporation, who wants to become the richest man in the world.  Scolex kills Bradford's father and steals the technology (evil is a foot) - but John gives chase.  After an explosion, John is in critical care and Scolex is minus a hand.  Before you can say, "Gentlemen, we can rebuild him..." John is reborn as the ultimate crimefighting machine.  Assorted stuff happens, evil is vanquished, kiss the girl, THE END.  You've seen it all before. It's Robocop without the violence.  The Mask without the humour.The story is nothing sensational or groundbreaking, but still, it had the potential to be a fun ride.  Alas, the film has a bland, paint by numbers feel to it.  There are no twists or turns.  The plot knows where it's going - as do we all - we just have to sit as the movie drudges its way there with one sight gag after another.  It feels as if the makers of the film had a checklist of "Things Kids Find Funny" and simply tacked them together.Toupe falling off.  check. Man drinks coffee, unaware something nasty's in it.  check. Spit take. check. Wise-cracking, black sidekick. Hmmm, been done a lot.  Better make him a talking car. check. Injury to the groin motif.  check.The effects are well done - a practicly seemless blend of classic film fx and cgi, but their overusage tends to dull their impact.  I can't wait for the day when studios get over their love affair with cgi and begin to use it sparingly.One thing that really distracted me was the film's usage of sound. Everything makes a noise - loud and greatly exaggerated.  There's not a silent second in the whole movie.  What bothers me about this is the philosophy behind it.  The studio's opinion is that if there's silence, people will loose interest.  So, like trying to entertain a cat, they stand there dangling their string calling to us repeatedly, making funny noises, all in a vain attempt to maintain our interest.  I'm sorry, but if you want my interest, then make an interesting film.The movie's editing leads me to believe that the original product and what ended up on the screen are two completely different creatures.  Sadly, I have a feeling that what ended up on the cutting room floor is the heart and soul of this picture - victim of countless focus groups of Joe Average (the same Joe Average that makes up the audiences at the Jerry Springer Show, I imagine) and executives who think their degrees in economics make them experts in storytelling.I've read a few reviews of the film since seeing it, and I see time and time again the flaws of the film brought up and then excused because, "It's a kid's film."  Look, our children are not stupid - stop treating them as if they were.  Sure, it'll get a few laughs from the tykes.  How could cat vomit in coffee not get a laugh from a five year old?  But will any of these kids remember this film a year from now?  A month from now?  I think we need to stop equating kids films with "crud".  A Fairy Tale, Babe, My Neighbour Totoro - these are kids films.  But this lifeless, humourless film called Inspector Gadget is only one thing - a wasted eight bucks.I give this film five out of five on the smelly piece of cheese scale.

The one thing i wanted to do after seeing this flick was to express my fury here within the user comments section. There is not a single set of lines in the whole movie coming close to a proper dialogue. Low-level humor, terrible acting, pointless and kinky directing, superficial characters make it absolutely unwatchable. There's really nothing ... what a shame for the cartoon series were very amusing. This is a disturbing disappointment and Disney will have a hard time to compensate for this disasterous production. If you somehow ununderstandably get into a room screening this movie you should immediately go go and escape mental violation.

Just here to say that this is the type of movie that you will either hate it or love it!  I personally thought it was good.  Many people are going to be mad that they stray from what happened in the TV series.  If the movie tried to duplicate everything in the TV series then it would have come across as cheap and annoying.  This way there is plenty new things in the movie to keep it interesting for young and old alike.  My only gripe is that they showed claw's face and he was a normal person!  (well, mostly anyway)

Despite watching some promising trailers, I was disappointed with this film. I think that it was aimed mainly at the younger generation of filmgoers and didn't really provide for anyone above 10. Acting seemed a little cheesy, which spoiled it for me. However, there are some excellent moments which will have you laughing your socks off and the special effects were truly amazing. It's really up to you to decide about this film, as I have heard many different opinions.

reviews.review_title: Someone definitely sold something to Satan
reviews.content: Until I saw this movie I assumed that sight was a gift, something to be cherished and appreciated. Now I know the truth, there are things out there that can make yearn badly to stab out your eyes with something fairly dull. I know "kids movies" are supposed to be a little less sophisticated and plot driven but subjecting children to this is abuse. Ferris, why hath thou forsaken us?
The idea is there, but wasn't pulled off. They should of just stuck to the cartoon.
This movie was one of the best classic movies I've ever seen, sure there was music at the wrong time and too much cartoon movement but this is still a great movie so ignore those bad reviews

reviews.review_title: Any episode of the original cartoon is funnier than this movie.
reviews.content: In keeping with Disney's well-known practice of stealing.. I mean.. buying out known properties and bastardizing them, this live-action version of the venerable cartoon classic has got to be one of the worst re-makes in a year of bad re-makes. I grew up on the original cartoon TV series. Any episode of the original cartoon series will give you more laughs than this entire movie. Not present is Penny's cool computer book. Also not present is the gag with the self-destructing orders that always ends up detonating on the Chief. New are a smooth talking Gadget convertible (the original cartoon had a cooler vehicle that could turn into a van or a car) and an element of a typical, unrealistic Hollywood romance. Don't fill the coffers to pay for Disney executives and even their _ex_executives - don't see this movie.

reviews.review_title: Great Cartoon turned into a bad Movie
reviews.content: The cartoon was much better. This movie ruins a beloved children's cartoon. The car was the worst part. I hate Brenda. Penny and Brain did nothing worth while in the movie. Claw was stupid, but the worst thing about claw was that you saw him! Gadget himself was okay but he was a little too smart to be Gadget. The thing I hated the most was the fact that Penny and Brain, who did everything in the cartoon, did next to nothing in the movie. I miss Penny's computer book.

I had absolutely nothing to do the past weekend, and tagged along with my friends to check out a movie...any movie. And since the only movie we'd not seen was Inspector Gadget, we decided to go in for that.BIG MISTAKE. This is a movie that might appeal only to kids. Oh, and it's not like I don't enjoy movies targeted at the younger audience. But this movie had absolutely nothing to hold my attention. If you have nothing to do at home, go to sleep. Better than wasting hard-earned cash on this. Go check out the film if you're a kid or if you're a parent with a kid :)

Had no expectations.  Tired of movies being panned by individuals with expectations of what they want to see, or expect to see.Laughed a lot, and wasn't bored. Since I am required to write at least four lines of review, I can only say that the out-takes... (trailers) looked good, but that as usual, I was willing to wait till the movie hit the video store prior to viewing it. Especially after it was panned.  However, my 7 year wanted to see it a second time, so I went along for the ride, and I was not disapointed.

When I went to see "Inspector Gadget", I wasn't expecting much; nothing more than a lame rip-off of my favorite cartoon. I left having seen (what I think) one of the top 5 movies of the summer. It cleverly combined the old cartoon with new special effects and explanations. Matthew Broderick is perfect (and adorable!) in the role of Gadget, though I found Michelle Trachtenburg's Penny to be a little irritating. Though "Gadget" has been, for the most part, slammed by critics, I found it to be hilarious. The slapstick wasn't forced and the dialogue was witty. I liked how it moved along quickly; before you were done laughing at one joke, the next one had already been delivered. Despite what critics say, definitely go out to see "Inspector Gadget", especially if you are or ever were a fan of the TV show!!

reviews.review_title: Okay if you have to take your kids to a movie
reviews.content: I can agree with Roger Ebert in saying that for adults the best part of this movie is that it's only about 80 minutes long.  It's not necessarily a bad movie, but it's so predictable that I felt like I had seen it before.  My major complaint was with Rupert Everett, who played Claw.  I guess he was supposed to be one of those super-intelligent villains, but his part was so poorly written that he came across as one of those guys that's so insecure that he has to use big words just to make himself feel better.  He never even seemed like a real threat.  Maybe it's because I was a kid, but in the cartoon, there was always that tiny doubt that the villain just might win this time.  There is not even a smidgen of that in this version.  I know this is a children's movie, but the villain can still be at least a little chilling!  Everett had not one single moment of evilness.Except for Claw, this movies was easy to sit through.  Again, I'll agree with Ebert and say that the Gadgetmobile is the best part of the movie, but in my opinion the car doesn't get enough scenes.  There are funny moments, and if you have to take your kids to a movie, there are a lot worse ones you could pick than this one.

Inspector Gadget is a great movie to take your little children to see. IT is very funny to watch! and beside Matthew Broderick wasn't that bad looking in the movie! GREAT MOVIE!!!!!!!!!!!! GO OUT  AND SEE THIS MOVIE!!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: Inspector Gadget 99 did the cartoon justice...and more!
reviews.content: Go Go Gadget...Two thumbs up!This film was funny, heart-felt, fast paced, cohesive and witty! The chemistry between the entire cast was perfect. I found myself chuckling through the entire movie b/c of all the little jokes and sarcastic comments that speckled the script.Matthew Broderick was flawless! He really brought the bumbling, yet loveable Inspector Gadget character back to life...and added his own unique twist to the part. He added a more humanized and comical aspect to the mechanized Gadget. He truly was Gadget.Rupert Everet's evil and convincing "Claw" villain added a sarcastic and evil wit to the movie, which helped keep the pace lively.The special effects and in this film blew me away entirely! They added a reality to this fantasy film, which I did not think was attainable! Mr. Broderick did a fantastic job in creating the evil Robo-Gadget character. Those teeth, his whiny cartoon voice (much like Don Adam's orginal Inspector Gadget character voice), and his evil bulging eyes created the perfect monster!One must keep in mind, though, that this IS a children's movie, based on a CARTOON...so it is no "Schindler's List." It is just a fun, silly flick to make you laugh. And although the character and premise is taken from the cartoon, one should not base their judgement or expectations of this film on the cartoon.The two negatives of this movie, that I could find, was (1) the lack of development of the relationship between Penny and the good Inspector. (2) The annoying Gadget Mobile with the bad attitude.PS:I am that glad Mr. Don Adams contributed to this picture with his short, but amusing cameo. After all, he WAS the one that originally brought Inspector Gadget to life!

After Disney's witty live-action George of the Jungle, I had high hopes for this flick.  Major disappointment. Thread bare plot, bad acting, bad visual effects.  This film relied on lame one-liners, idiotic ( and pointless) product placement, and the lamest most annoying side-kick in that gadget car thing.  I took two young kids to see it and they where bored out of their mind.  The only laugh received from this movie was bad standby of when needing a laugh show a guy getting it in the groin!

Not having seen any reviews about the movie I really didn't know what to expect.  However, when I found out it was a Disney movie and that it starred Matthew Broderick, I figured it's got to be pretty good.  Well, it wasn't. It was terrible.  Stupid humor, terrible development of plot and bad acting. Almost seemed as if the actors were simply putting in their time, but none of their effort.  Don't bother with this one.

It was painful to watch such fine actors as Matthew Broderick and Rupert Everett stumble through this horrible mess of a movie. How Broderick could make this and the wonderfully subversive Election is beyond me.I will admit it is a children's movie and not a work of art, but at least the cartoon was entertaining. This remake, one of endless TV remakes, is just STUPID! The only bright moment is Cheri O'Teri's all too short performance as the mayor.

reviews.review_title: This actually managed to be physically painful.
reviews.content: I didn't realize they could butcher a concept so thoroughly.  Instead of the Penny/Gadget/Brain dynamic of the series, you have a confused and overloaded cast that seems to pander to every stereotype you can think of.  Why the emphasis on the car?  Why turn Penny from the true detective of the series to just an annoying kid?I feel sorry for Rupert Everett, too.  He doesn't look very comfortable with his role at the best of times.
